PREFACE This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Jesup, Georgia. Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1976 Code, as supplemented through November 1999, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board of commissioners. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1976 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. Chapter and Section Numbering System The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. Page Numbering System The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes:
Indexes The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. Looseleaf Supplements A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. Acknowledgments This publication was under the direct supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Senior Code Attorney, and Leesa Hampton, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. The publisher is most grateful to Mike Deal, City Manager, and O'nda Woodard, City Clerk for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. Copyright All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Jesup, Georgia. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Jesup, Georgia. © Copyrighted material. Municipal Code Corporation and the City of Jesup, Georgia. 2005. AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF JESUP, GEORGIA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ARTICLE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. BE IT ORDAINED BY THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF THE CITY OF JESUP: Section 1. The Code entitled "The Code of the City of Jesup, Georgia," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 106, each inclusive, is adopted. Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before June 20, 2006, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this article. Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imprisonment in the city or county jail and work and labor on the streets or public works of the city, whether within or without the corporate limits, not exceeding 180 days, or both a fine and sentence of imprisonment and labor; and all sentences may be in the alternative and fines may be imposed with the alternative of sentence to imprisonment and labor if the fines are not paid. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the City may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the City to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. Section 6. Ordinances adopted after June 20, 2006, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. Section 7. Passed and adopted this _____ day of ___________, 2006.

SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Includes." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the code's historical evolution.
PART I - CHARTER[1]

PART I - CHARTER[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— This Charter of the City of Jesup, Georgia, enacted by an ordinance adopted January 2, 2018, amended the former Jesup New Charter No. 34 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Charter §§ 1—134, derived from Act No. 34 of Georgia Laws of 1937-8, page 1142 et seq., approved December 16, 1937. Amendments to the Charter are indicated by notes following the affected sections showing the source of such amendments. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. Additions for clarity and indicated by brackets.
AMENDED AND RESTATED CHARTER ARTICLE 1. - INCORPORATION AND POWERS
1.1 - Name. The City of Jesup, Georgia and the inhabitants thereof, are reincorporated by the enactment of this Amended and Restated Charter and are hereby again constituted and declared a body politic and corporate under the name and style of the City of Jesup, Georgia, and by that name shall have perpetual succession. (Ord. of 1-2-2018) 1.2 - Charter. This Amendment shall constitute the Amended and Restated Charter of the City of Jesup, Georgia adopted by the Mayor and Board of Commissioners of the City of Jesup, Georgia (also the "City"), pursuant to The Municipal Home Rule Act of 1965 at GA. CODE ANN. § 36-35-1 (2016) et seq. and other applicable provisions of Georgia law (hereinafter the "Charter"). The City of Jesup, Georgia, in the County of Wayne, and the inhabitants thereof, are constituted and declared a body politic and corporate under the same name and style of the "City of Jesup" and by that name shall have perpetual duration and succession. In addition to those other powers, rights, and privileges set forth in this Charter and as otherwise may exist under the general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia or the City of Jesup may contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts of law and equity, make and enact, by and through its Mayor and Board of Commissioners, ordinances, resolutions, by-laws, rules, regulations, policies and procedures, use a common seal, and, in all actions whatsoever, exercise, enjoy, employ and implement any and all other powers, rights, and privileges incident to municipal corporations of this State, or cites thereof, as authorized by and under the general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia or the acts of the Georgia General Assembly or the Constitution of the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 1-2-2018) 1.3 - Corporate Limits. The boundaries of this City shall be those existing on the effective date of the adoption of this Charter with such alterations as may be made from time to time in a manner provided by law. Specifically, the corporate limits of the City of Jesup shall extend to and embrace all of the following described territory, to-wit: Beginning at a point located 46° 30' west a distance of 9,280.0 feet from the point of intersection of the center of Cherry Street and the center of the main line track of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad in said City; thence north 43° 30' east a distance of 9,280.0 feet; thence south 46° 30' east a distance of 18,560 feet; thence south 43° 30' west a distance of 23,560.0 feet; thence north 46° 30' west a distance of 18,560.0 feet; thence north 43° 30' east a distance of 14,280 feet to the point of beginning. The boundaries of this City at all times shall be shown on a map, a written description or any combination thereof, to be retained permanently in the office of the City Clerk and to be designated, as the case may be: "Official Map (or Description) of the Corporate Limits of the City of Jesup, Georgia." Photographic, typed, or other copies of such map or description certified by the City Clerk shall be admitted as evidence in all courts and shall have the same force and effect as the original map or description. The Mayor and the Board of Commissioners of the City of Jesup may provide for the redrawing of any such map, by ordinance, to reflect lawful changes in the corporate boundaries. A redrawn map shall supersede, for all purposes, the entire map or maps which it is designated to replace. (Ord. of 1-2-2018) 1.4 - Powers Generally. All powers, functions, rights, privileges, and immunities of the City of Jesup, its officers, agencies, or employees as exist from time-to-time under general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia or the acts of the Georgia General Assembly or the Constitution of the State of Georgia, shall be carried into execution as provided by this Charter. The powers of the City of Jesup shall be construed liberally in favor of the City of Jesup and shall include all powers under the general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia, the acts of the Georgia General Assembly, the Constitution of the State of Georgia, or under this Charter. The specific mention or failure to mention particular powers shall not be construed as limiting in any way the powers of the City of Jesup. If this Charter makes no provision, such shall be carried into execution as provided by ordinance or as provided by pertinent laws of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia. At all times during its perpetual existence, the City of Jesup shall exercise, enjoy and be entitled to the powers, rights, and privileges set forth in this Charter and as otherwise exist under the general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia, the acts of the Georgia General Assembly or the Constitution of the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 1-2-2018) 1.5 - Powers Illustrated. Without limiting the foregoing, the City of Jesup shall also have the following additional powers, functions, rights, privileges, and immunities: 1.5.1 Alcohol regulations. To regulate the sale, possession, distribution, consumption, manufacture, transportation and taxation of alcoholic beverages, wine, spirits, liquors, cider and related beverages and products; to provide for the issuance of licenses for the sale, possession, distribution, consumption, manufacture, transportation and taxation of alcoholic beverages or products and the establishment of standards related to such licenses; to provide for zoning, land use and related restrictions on real property and land related to property and premises involved in the sale, possession, distribution, consumption, manufacture, transportation and taxation of alcoholic beverages or products. 1.5.2 Animal regulations. To regulate and license or to prohibit the keeping, harboring, maintenance or running at-large of animals, fishes and fowl, and to provide for the impoundment of the same, if in violation of any ordinance or lawful order; to provide for the disposition by sale, gift, or humane destruction of animals, fishes and fowl when not redeemed as provided by ordinance; and to provide punishment for violation of ordinances enacted hereunder. 1.5.3 Appropriations and expenditures. To make appropriations for the support of the government of the City of Jesup; to authorize the expenditure of money for any purpose authorized by this Charter and for any purpose for which a municipality is authorized by the laws of the State of Georgia; and to provide for the payment of expenses of the City of Jesup. 1.5.4 Building regulation. To regulate and to license the erection and construction of buildings and all other structures within the City of Jesup; to adopt building, housing, plumbing, electrical, gas, fire, life-safety, property-maintenance and heating and air conditioning codes; and to regulate all housing and building trades to the extent permitted under the general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia, the acts of the Georgia General Assembly or the Constitution of the State of Georgia. 1.5.5 Business regulation and taxation. To levy and to provide for the collection of regulatory fees and taxes on privileges, occupations, trades, businesses, and professions as authorized by Title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or such other applicable laws as are or may hereafter be enacted by the Georgia General Assembly; to permit and regulate the same; to provide for the manner and method of payment of such regulatory fees and taxes; to revoke such permits; and to generally regulate trade, business, occupations and professions within the geographical and jurisdictional limits of the City of Jesup. 1.5.6 Cemeteries. To provide for the creation, construction, and maintenance of a cemetery or cemeteries for the interment of human remains. 1.5.7 Codification of Ordinances. To codify all ordinances of the City of Jesup, together with this Charter, into one book to be known as "The Code of the City of Jesup." 1.5.8 Commercial Development. To provide for standards, rules, regulations, and incentives, as permitted by general laws of statewide application, for the development of trade, business, commerce, employment opportunities, and real property improvement. 1.5.9 Condemnation. 1.5.9.1 Power. To condemn property for present or future use and for any public purpose deemed necessary by the Mayor and Board of Commissioners of the City of Jesup, utilizing procedures enumerated in Title 22 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, or such other applicable laws of the State of Georgia as are or may hereafter be enacted; and 1.5.9.2 Removal and Remediation. To remove, replace and cause to be remediated or removed any building, structure, or existing condition upon real property and land within the City of Jesup's corporate limits that is, or are, dangerous to life, limb, persons, or property, by reasons of decay, dilapidation, or unsanitary or dangerous conditions. Nothing in this subparagraph shall be construed to relieve the City of Jesup of any duty to provide owners or interested persons reasonable notice and opportunity to remedy an underlying condition necessitating removal and remediation. This subparagraph shall not be construed as authorizing the doing of any act or thing contrary to the Constitution of the State of Georgia or the laws of the State of Georgia. The City of Jesup shall have authority to adopt reasonable ordinances and resolutions for the purpose of carrying out this subparagraph. 1.5.10 Construction, Building and Property Maintenance Standards. To provide for minimum standards, regulations, rules and regulations related to construction, improvement, remodeling, repair, building, erection and maintenance of buildings, houses, structures, and improvements on real property and land. 1.5.11 Contracts. To enter into contracts and agreements with other governmental entities and with private persons, associations of persons, firms, partnerships, corporations, limited liability companies, organizations, joint ventures or other parties. 1.5.12 Emergencies. To establish procedures for determining and proclaiming that an emergency exists within or without the City of Jesup and to make and carry out all reasonable provisions deemed necessary to address or meet such emergencies for the protection, safety, health, or the well-being of the public at large. 1.5.13 Environmental protection. To protect and preserve the natural resources, physical and aesthetic environment, and vital geographic, geologic, hydrologic and historically-significant areas of the City of Jesup, the region, and the State of Georgia through the enactment of ordinances that preserve and improve air quality, restore and maintain water resources, control erosion and sedimentation, manage storm-water and establish a storm-water utility, manage solid and hazardous waste, provide for disposal of solid waste and inert materials and provide other necessary or beneficial actions for the protection of the environment. 1.5.14 Ethics. To adopt ethics ordinances and regulations governing such matters including, but not limited to, the conduct of elected municipal officials, appointed officials, contractors, vendors, and employees; establishing procedures for ethics complaints; and setting forth penalties for violations of such rules and procedures. 1.5.15 Fire and public safety regulations. To fix and establish fire-safety, life-safety, building and construction, and public-safety codes, rules, prohibitions, regulations, limitations and restrictions and, from time to time, to extend, enlarge, or restrict the same; to prescribe fire-safety, life-safety, building and construction, and public-safety codes, rules, prohibitions, regulations, limitations and restrictions not inconsistent with general laws of statewide application, relating to fire prevention and detection, public safety, crime prevention, firefighting and other matters generally affecting public health, safety, and welfare; and to prescribe penalties and punishment for violations thereof; and similar regulations for the overall promotion and preservation of public health, safety, and welfare. 1.5.16 Food Preparation and Delivery. To provide for codes, rules, prohibitions, regulations, limitations and restrictions related to the preparation, manufacture, distribution, dissemination or handling of food or other products intended for human consumption, and the premises or structures or vehicles and equipment utilized in such activities. 1.5.17 Garbage services and fees. To provide for the collection, accumulation, storage and disposal of garbage, waste, trash, refuse and similar items; and to levy, fix, assess, and collect garbage, refuse, trash collection and disposal and other sanitary service charge, taxes or fees; to enforce the payment of such charges, taxes, or fees; and to provide for the manner and method of collecting such service charges, taxes, or fees. 1.5.18 General health, safety, and welfare. To define, regulate, and prohibit any act, practice, conduct, or use of property which is detrimental to the health, sanitation, cleanliness, welfare, and safety of the general public and the City of Jesup and its inhabitants, citizens, businesses, and visitors; to provide for the enforcement of such standards; and to provide for the proper maintenance and disposal of wastes and debris. 1.5.19 Gifts. To accept or refuse gifts, donations, bequests, or grants from any source for any purpose legally permitted under the general laws of statewide application of the State of Georgia and the Georgia Constitution, and including on such terms and conditions as the donor or grantor may impose. 1.5.20 Health and sanitation. To prescribe standards of health, cleanliness, and sanitation and to provide for the enforcement of such standards. 1.5.21 Homestead exemption. To establish and maintain procedures for offering homestead exemptions to residents of the City of Jesup and maintaining current homestead exemptions of residents of the City of Jesup as authorized under the laws of the State of Georgia and the Georgia Constitution. 1.5.22 Inquiries and investigations. To make inquiries and investigations into the affairs of the City of Jesup and conduct of any department, office, or agency thereof and for this purpose may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths, take testimony, and require the production of evidence. Any person who fails or refuses to obey a lawful order issued in the exercise of these powers by the Mayor and the Board of Commissioners of the City of Jesup shall be punished as may be provided by applicable ordinances or applicable laws of the State of Georgia. 1.5.23 Jail sentences. To provide that persons given jail sentences in the City of Jesup's Municipal Court may work out such sentences in any public works or on the streets, roads, drains, and other public property in the City of Jesup; to provide for commitment of such persons to any jail; to provide for the use of pretrial diversion and any alternative sentencing allowed by under the laws of the State of Georgia and the Georgia Constitution; or to provide for commitment of such persons to any county work camp or county jail. 1.5.24 Motor vehicles. To regulate the operation of motor vehicles and pedestrian traffic, and to exercise control over all traffic of any form, including parking in, upon, across or over the highways, thoroughfares, streets, roads, alleys, lanes, sidewalks and walkways of the City of Jesup; to provide for the orderly operation of vehicles and equipment within the City of Jesup; and to provide for the safe, efficient and orderly control of traffic in, upon, across or over the highways, thoroughfares, streets, roads, alleys, lanes, sidewalks and walkways of the City of Jesup. 1.5.25 Municipal agencies and delegation of power. To create, alter, or abolish departments, boards, agencies, authorities, departments, boards, agencies, authorities, and offices of the City of Jesup and to confer upon such departments, boards, agencies, authorities, and offices the necessary and appropriate authorities, powers, rights and entitlements to effectuate their respective purposes. 1.5.26 Municipal courts. To create a municipal court with a judge or judges and associate judges as may be necessary, and to authorize the creation of a municipal court clerk's office or similar office as appointed by the Mayor and Board of Commissioners. The Clerk of the City of Jesup may be authorized to perform such duties, if appointed, and may occupy such role. The Board of Commissioners and the City of Jesup, though having the power and authority to do so, is under no obligation to create a municipal court clerk or similar office, and is likewise not under obligation to have the City Clerk perform such duties. 1.5.27 Municipal debts. To incur debts, obligations, encumbrances, liabilities and commitments as authorized by this Charter, the laws of the State of Georgia, and the Georgia Constitution; to both appropriate and borrow money for the payment of such debts, obligations, encumbrances, liabilities and commitments of the City of Jesup; to pledge the credit of the City of Jesup as authorized by this Charter, the laws of the State of Georgia, and the Georgia Constitution; and to issue bonds, mortgages, indentures, and other security instruments as authorized by this Charter, the laws of the State of Georgia, and the Georgia Constitution. 1.5.28 Municipal property ownership. To acquire, dispose of, lease, and hold in trust or otherwise any real, personal, or mixed property, in fee simple or lesser interest, inside or outside of the geographical limitations of the City of Jesup. 1.5.29 Municipal property protection. To provide for the preservation and protection of all property and equipment of the City of Jesup and the administration and use of same by the public and to prescribe penalties and punishment for violations thereof. 1.5.30 Municipal utilities. To acquire, lease, construct, operate, maintain, sell, and dispose of public utilities, including, but not limited to: a system of waterworks, water pumping plants and accessories, wells, cisterns, towers, water mains, piping, sewers and drains, sewage disposal, storm-water management, gas works, electricity generating plants, cable television and other telecommunications, transportation facilities, public airports, and any other public utility; to fix the taxes, charges, rates, fares, fees, assessments, regulations, and penalties for all such public utilities; and to provide for the withdrawal of service for refusal or failure to pay the same. 1.5.31 Nuisance. To define a nuisance and provide for its abatement whether on public or private property. 1.5.32 Penalties. To provide penalties for violation of any ordinances adopted pursuant to the authority of this Charter and the laws of the State of Georgia. 1.5.33 Planning and zoning. To provide for comprehensive City planning, to pass and adopt ordinances, rules and regulations for land use, zoning, restrictions on the use of real property and regulations for the development and maintenance of real property, signage, buildings, structures, and outside advertising; and to provide subdivision regulation, all to ensure a safe, healthy, and aesthetically pleasing community. 1.5.34 Police and fire protection. To exercise the power of arrest through law enforcement and authorized officers and to establish, operate or contract for police and fire-fighting agencies. 1.5.35 Public hazards: removal. To provide for the destruction and removal of any building or other structure or physical condition, which is or may become, dangerous, unsanitary, or detrimental to the public health, welfare or interest. 1.5.36 Public improvements. To provide for the acquisition, construction, building, operation, maintenance, or abolition of water and sewer systems, highways and streets, alleys, lanes, thoroughfares and roads, public ways, parks and playgrounds, recreational facilities, cemeteries, public buildings, libraries, public housing, parking facilities, and charitable, cultural, educational, recreational, conservation, sport, detention, penal, and medical institutions, agencies, and any facilities or improvements necessary to promote and protect the public health, wellbeing, and safety of the citizens of and visitors to the City of Jesup; to provide any other public improvements and to regulate the use of public improvements. For such purposes, property may be acquired by condemnation under Title 22 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or such other applicable laws as are or may hereafter be enacted. 1.5.37 Public peace. To provide for the prevention and punishment of loitering, disorderly conduct, drunkenness, riots, and public disturbances. 1.5.38 Public transportation. To organize and operate or to participate in the operation of such public transportation systems as are deemed beneficial by the Mayor and Board of Commissioners of the City of Jesup. To the extent permitted by federal and state law, the Mayor and Board of Commissioners may provide, by ordinance, for the regulation of buses, trains, trolleys, streetcars, or other forms of public transportation operating in or traveling through the City of Jesup. 1.5.39 Public utilities and services. To grant franchises or make contracts for, or impose taxes on, public utilities and public service companies; and to prescribe the rates, fares, regulations, and standards and conditions of service applicable to the service to be provided by the franchise grantee or contractor, insofar as not in conflict with valid regulations of the Georgia Public Service Commission or its successor. 1.5.40 Purchasing. To make purchases of, or to otherwise lawfully acquire, goods, services, equipment, vehicles, and supplies. 1.5.41 Regulation of roadside areas. To prohibit or regulate and control the erection, removal, and maintenance of signs, billboards, trees, shrubs, fences, buildings, and any and all other structures or obstructions upon or adjacent to the rights of way of streets and roads or within view thereof, within or abutting the geographic limitations and boundaries of the City of Jesup; and to prescribe penalties and punishment for violation of such ordinances. 1.5.42 Remedy unsafe and unsanitary conditions. To remediate, remove, or cause or order to be remediated or removed, any building, structure, or existing condition within the City of Jesup's corporate limits that is dangerous to life, limb, persons, or property, by reasons of decay, dilapidation, or unsanitary or dangerous conditions pursuant to the City of Jesup's power to regulate the health, safety and welfare of its citizens. 1.5.43 Retirement and employee benefits. To provide and maintain a retirement plan, insurance, and such other employee benefits for appointed officers and employees of the City of Jesup as may be determined from time-to-time by the Mayor and Board of Commissioners. 1.5.44 Roadways. To build, construct, design, lay out, open, extend, widen, narrow, establish or change the grade of, abandon or close, construct, pave, curb, gutter, adorn with shade trees, or otherwise improve, maintain, repair, clean, prevent erosion of, and light the highways, thoroughfares, roads, streets, alleys, lanes, sidewalks and walkways within the geographic limitations and boundaries of the City of Jesup; to grant franchises and rights of way throughout those streets and roads and over the bridges and viaducts for the use of public utilities; and to require real estate owners to repair and maintain in a safe condition the sidewalks adjoining their lots or lands and to impose penalties for failure to do so. 1.5.45 Sewer Fees. To levy a fee, charge, or tax as necessary to assure the acquiring, constructing, equipping, operating, maintaining, and extending of a sewage disposal plant and sewerage system, and to levy on those to whom sewers and sewerage systems are made available a sewer service fee, charge or sewer tax for the availability or use of the sewers; to provide for the manner and method of collecting such service charges and for enforcing payment of the same; and to charge, impose and collect a connection fee or fees to those connected with the system. 1.5.46 Solid waste disposal. To provide for the collection and disposal of garbage, rubbish, and refuse and to regulate the collection and disposal of garbage, rubbish, and refuse by others; and to provide for the separate collection of glass, tin, aluminum, cardboard, paper, and other recyclable materials and to provide for the sale of such items, refuse, or their byproducts, when feasible to do so. 1.5.47 Special assessments. To levy and provide for the collection of special assessments for any public improvements as may be permitted by this Charter, the general laws of the State of Georgia, and Georgia Constitution. 1.5.48 Special Areas of Public Regulation. To regulate or prohibit junk dealers, and the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors; to regulate the transportation, storage and use of combustible, explosive and inflammable materials, the use of lighting and heating equipment, and any other business or situation which may be dangerous to persons or property; to regulate and control the conduct of peddlers and itinerant traders, theatrical performances, exhibitions, and shows of any kind, by taxation or otherwise; to license and tax professional fortunetelling, palmistry, and massage parlors; and to restrict adult novelty and bookstores to certain areas. 1.5.49 Taxes; ad valorem. To levy and provide for the assessment, valuation, revaluation, and collection of taxes on all property subject to taxation. All such valuations will be performed in accordance with general laws of statewide application. 1.5.50 Taxes; other. To levy and collect such other taxes and fees as may be allowed now or in the future by law. 1.5.51 Taxes. To impose, pass, enforce and collect and taxes or fees that are permitted by law. 1.5.52 Taxes on Insurance Premiums. The Mayor and Board of Commissioners are hereby empowered and authorized to assess, levy and collect a tax on fire, life, casualty and accident insurance premiums which are collected from policy holders residing in said city or when any policy holder resides out of the City of Jesup, but the property insured is located in said city, and said tax may be in addition to any other license, tax or fee the said city may be authorized to collect from insurance companies or their agents doing business in said city. 1.5.53 Taxicabs. To regulate and license vehicles operated for hire in the City of Jesup; to limit the number of such vehicles; to require the operators thereof to be licensed; to require public liability insurance on such vehicles in the amounts to be prescribed by ordinance; to inspect such vehicles and mandate standards of safety and cleanliness; and to regulate the parking of such vehicles. 1.5.54 Tourism, conventions, and trade shows. To authorize the City of Jesup to contract with private sector, nonprofit organizations, or other governmental agencies to promote tourism, conventions, and trade shows. 1.5.55 Urban redevelopment. To organize and operate an urban redevelopment program. 1.5.56 Water Fees. To levy a fee, charge, or tax as necessary to assure the acquiring, constructing, equipping, operating, maintaining, and extending of a water treatment plant and water system, and to levy on those to whom water and water systems are made available a water service fee, charge or water tax for the availability or use of the water; to provide for the manner and method of collecting such service charges and for enforcing payment of the same; and to charge, impose and collect a connection fee or fees to those connected with the system. 1.5.57 Other powers. To exercise and enjoy all other powers, functions, rights, privileges, and immunities necessary or desirable to promote or protect the safety, health, peace, security, good order, comfort, convenience, or general welfare of the City of Jesup and its inhabitants; to exercise all implied powers necessary or desirable to carry into execution all powers granted in this Charter as fully and completely as if such powers were fully stated herein; and to exercise all powers now or in the future authorized to be exercised by other municipal governments under other laws of the State of Georgia; and any listing of particular powers in this Charter shall not be held to be exclusive of others or restrictive of general words and phrases granting powers but shall be held to be in addition to such powers unless expressly prohibited to municipalities under the Constitution or applicable laws of the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 1-2-2018) ARTICLE 2. - GOVERNMENT STRUCTURE
2.1 - Administration. The legislative authority of the government of the City of Jesup, Georgia, except as otherwise specifically provided in this Charter, shall be vested in the duly-elected Commissioners of the City of Jesup (or appointed as is otherwise permitted in this Charter) and its duly-elected Mayor (or, again, appointed as is otherwise permitted in this Charter). The Board of Commissioners and Mayor shall be elected in the manner provided by this Charter and as otherwise mandated by the Georgia Constitution and general laws of statewide application or appointed in the event of the occurrence of a vacancy in the office of Commissioner or Mayor as otherwise set forth herein.
