div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of municipality to adopt ordinances, resolutions or regulations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3(a).
Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. The provisions in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as "The Code of the City of Jesup, Georgia," and may be so cited. Such code may also be known and cited as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Jesup, Georgia," or as the "Jesup City Code." (Code 1976, § 1-1) Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of commissioners or the context clearly requires otherwise: Advice and consent. The term "advice and consent" of the board of commissioners shall mean an affirmative vote of the majority of the entire board of commissioners. Board of commissioners and the board. The term "board of commissioners" and "the board" shall mean the board of commissioners of the City of Jesup, Georgia. Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. City. The term "the city" shall mean the City of Jesup in the County of Wayne and the State of Georgia, except as otherwise provided. Code. The term "Code" shall mean The Code of the City of Jesup, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. Computation of time. Except as otherwise provided by time period computations specifically applying to other laws, when a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years or other measurements of time, except hours, is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. County. The term "county" or "the county" shall mean the County of Wayne, State of Georgia. Day. The term "day" shall mean a calendar day of 24 hours. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. Joint authority. All words giving joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers, except when such words are used to grant authority to the board of commissioners. Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, receivers, trustees, personal representatives, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. Month. The term "month" shall mean a calendar month. Names of officers and departments. The name or title of any officer or department shall be read as though the words "of the City of Jesup" were added to such name or title. Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. Number. Words used in the singular include the plural, and the plural includes the singular number. Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath; and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. Or and and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. Owner. The term "owner," when applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such building or land. Penal ordinances. The rules of construction and definitions of words as contained in the penal code of the state, insofar as they can be made applicable, are adopted as governing the penal ordinances of the city. Person. The term "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property, except real property. Preceding and following. The terms "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. Premises. The term "premises" shall mean a place or places. Property. The term "property" shall include real and personal property. Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, schoolyard or adjacent open space, or any area available and/or accessible to the public, regardless of whether privately or publicly owned. Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. Residence. The term "residence" shall mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. Schedule of fees and charges. The term "schedule of fees and charges" shall mean the official consolidated list maintained in the city clerk's office, which lists rates for utility or other public enterprises, fees of any nature, deposit amounts and various charges as determined by the board of commissioners. Seal. The term "seal" shall mean the city seal. Shall and may. The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. Sheriff. The term "sheriff" shall mean the sheriff of Wayne County, Georgia. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians, but shall not include any unimproved areas between the curbline and improved walkways. Signature and subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write. State. The term "state" or "the state" shall mean the State of Georgia. Street. The term "street" shall mean and include any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, lane, viaduct or bridge and their approaches within the city. Tenant and occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," when applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. Tense. Terms used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Week. The term "week" shall mean a calendar week of seven days. Written and in writing. The terms "written" and "in writing" shall include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. Year. The term "year" shall mean a calendar year. (Code 1976, § 1-2) State Law reference— Computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; construction of definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; meaning of certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3. Sec. 1-3. - Section catchlines and other headings. The catchlines of sections in this Code printed in boldface type, italics or otherwise are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. (Code 1976, § 1-9) State Law reference— Notes and catchlines of Code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - References to portions of Code. All references to chapters, articles, divisions or sections are to the chapters, articles, divisions and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. (Code 1976, § 1-4) Sec. 1-5. - Provisions considered continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, as far as they are the same as ordinances adopted prior to this Code and included in such Code, shall be considered as continuations and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-6. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (2) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness. (3) Any contract or obligation assumed by the city. (4) Any ordinance fixing the salary of any city officer or employee. (5) Any right or franchise granted by the city. (6) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city. (7) Any appropriation ordinance. (8) Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term. (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements. (10) Any zoning ordinance. (11) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat. (12) Any ordinance describing or altering the boundaries of the city. (13) The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. (14) Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code. (15) Any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city. (b) No such ordinance shall be construed to revive any ordinance or part of an ordinance that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this chapter. All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Sec. 1-7. - Conflicting provisions. (a) If the provisions of different chapters of this Code conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter shall prevail as to all matters and questions growing out of the subject matter of such chapter. (b) If conflicting provisions are found in different sections of the same chapter, the provisions of the section which is last in numerical order shall prevail unless such construction is inconsistent with the meaning of such chapter. (Code 1976, § 1-5) Sec. 1-8. - Parenthetical and reference matter. The matter in parentheses at the ends of sections is for information only and is not a part of the Code. Citations to the 1976 Code of the city (Code 1976) and to later ordinances indicate only the source and the text may or may not be changed by this Code. Reference matter not in parentheses is for information only and is not a part of this Code. (Code 1976, § 1-6) Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. It is declared to be the intention of the board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable; and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code since they would have been enacted by the board of commissioners without the incorporation in the Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1976, § 1-10) State Law reference— Severability, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3. Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by addition or deletion any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions of pages, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented, unless so authorized by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the board of commissioners. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. (Code 1976, § 1-7) State Law reference— Altering, falsifying or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1. Sec. 1-11. - General penalty; continuing violations. (a) Whenever in this Code or any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required and the failure to do such act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided, and unless otherwise provided by state law, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imprisonment in the city or county jail and work and labor on the streets or public works of the city, whether within or without the corporate limits, not exceeding 180 days, or both a fine and sentence of imprisonment and labor; and all sentences may be in the alternative and fines may be imposed with the alternative of sentence to imprisonment and labor if the fines are not paid. Each day any violation of this Code or any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (b) The judge of the municipal court shall have the power and authority to: (1) Impose upon persons convicted in the municipal court the fines provided for in this Code, the ordinances of the city or as otherwise provided by law, with the alternative of other punishment allowed by law, if such fines are not paid; (2) Sentence such person to community service work; or (3) Impose a sentence consisting of any combination of the penalties provided for in this section. (c) The judge of the municipal court shall have full power and authority to declare the forfeiture of bonds given by offenders for their appearance before the municipal court upon the offender's failure to appear as provided for in such bond. The procedure for the forfeiture of such bonds shall be as provided for the forfeiture of bonds and recognizance as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 17-6-70 et seq. (Code 1976, § 1-8) State Law reference— Imposition of additional penalty for certain drug offenses, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-100; imposition of additional penalty for offense of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-112; additional penalty to be imposed in criminal and traffic cases to provide training to law enforcement officers and prosecuting officials, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; additional penalty assessments for jail construction and staffing, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-93; punishment for misdemeanors generally, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; deposit of drivers license for violations of laws pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11; payments to peace officers annuity and benefit fund from revenues collected from fines and fees, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 et seq.; alternative punishments for violations involving a traffic offense, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3(e).

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(3); any administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(13); administrative procedures for buildings and building regulations, § 18-61 et seq.; civil emergencies, ch. 30; courts, ch. 34; finances, ch. 42; administration and enforcement of flood damage prevention, § 46-61 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 58; planning and zoning, ch. 70; taxation, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 98; administration, enforcement and penalties of zoning regulations, app. A, § 101 et seq. State Law reference— Municipalities generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-3-30 et seq.; powers of municipalities generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-1 et seq.; powers relating to administration of municipal government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; the Municipal Home Rule Act of 1965, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; provisions applicable to counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-1 et seq.; provisions applicable to counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-2 et seq.; home rule for municipalities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ II; supplemental powers of municipalities and counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Official tree. The dogwood is named as the official tree of the city. (Code 1976, § 2-1) Sec. 2-2. - Official flower. The day lily is designated as the official flower of the city. (Code 1976, § 2-2) Secs. 2-3—2-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Code of ethics for government service, O.C.G.A. § 45-10-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-31. - Regular meetings. The board of commissioners of the city shall hold regular meetings on the first Tuesday of each calendar month. The hour fixed for any such regular meeting may be specially set by the board of commissioners by majority vote of the commissioners. In the absence of any specially set hour for any such regular meeting or series of meetings, regular meetings otherwise shall commence at seven o'clock post meridian (7:00 p.m.). When the day fixed for any such regular meeting falls on a day designated as a federal or state holiday, such meeting shall be held on the next succeeding Tuesday at the hour originally specially set for such meeting by majority vote of the board of commissioners or at seven o'clock post meridian (7:00 p.m.) if no such hour was specially set. Nothing contained herein shall otherwise prohibit, restrict, or prevent the board of commissioners of the city from calling, holding, convening or participating in any specially-called meeting or work session of the board of commissioners as otherwise permitted under the Code of the city. Regular meetings of the board of commissioners of the city shall be held at City Hall in Jesup, Georgia. The board of commissioners may, however, specially fix an alternative location for any such meeting by majority vote of the commissioners. (Code 1976, § 2-14; Ord. of 5-3-2016) Sec. 2-32. - Special meetings. A special meeting of the board of commissioners may be held at the call of any three commissioners. Whenever a special meeting is called, notice shall be given by the clerk of the commissioners to each member of the board of commissioners setting forth the date, hour and place of the meeting, and the purpose for which the meeting is called, and no business shall be transacted at such special meeting, except such as is given in the notice, without the unanimous consent of the entire board of commissioners. (Code 1976, § 2-15) Sec. 2-33. - Meeting agenda. All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contract documents or other matter to be submitted to the board of commissioners shall, be delivered to the city manager at least 30 hours prior to each meeting of the board of commissioners, whereupon the city manager shall immediately arrange a list of such matters according to the order of business and furnish each member of the board of commissioners with a copy of the list at least 24 hours prior to the meeting. (Code 1976, § 2-16) Sec. 2-34. - Presiding officer and mayor pro tem. (a) The mayor shall be the presiding officer of the board of commissioners, or in his absence or disqualification, the mayor pro tem. It shall be the duty of the presiding officer to preserve order and decorum at all meetings, to state every question coming before the board, announce the decision of the board on all subjects and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal to the board, in which event, a majority vote of the board shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order. (b) The office of mayor pro tem is to be filled by a commissioner from one of the commission districts for a term of one year. After the commissioner representing District 1 serves for a term of one year, the commissioner representing District 2 shall serve for a term of one year. After the commissioner representing District 2 serves for a term of one year, the commissioner representing District 3 shall serve for a term of one year. After the commissioner representing District 3 serves for a term of one year, the commissioner representing District 4 shall serve for a term of one year. After the commissioner representing District 4 serves for a term of one year, the commissioner representing District 5 shall serve for a term of one year. After the commissioner representing District 5 serves for a term of one year, the commissioner representing District 6 shall serve for a term of one year. After the commissioner representing District 6 serves for a term one year, the commissioner representing District 1 serves for a term of one year. (Code 1976, § 2-17) Sec. 2-35. - Mayor's vote. The mayor shall have the right to vote only in the case of a tie vote of the commissioners voting on any matter. (Code 1976, § 2-18) Sec. 2-36. - Call to order. The presiding officer shall take the chair precisely at the hour appointed for the meeting of the board of commissioners, and shall immediately call the board to order. (Code 1976, § 2-19) Sec. 2-37. - Roll call. Before proceeding with the business of the board of commissioners, the city clerk or his deputy may call the roll of the members of the board, and the name of those present shall be entered in the minutes. (Code 1976, § 2-20) Sec. 2-38. - Quorum. Four members of the board of commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business pertaining to the city. In the absence of a quorum, the presiding officer shall, at the instance of any member, compel the attendance of absent members; provided, however, the enactment of any ordinance or resolution, or the passage of any motion, or the transaction of any business requiring a vote of the board shall require at least four votes of the board. (Code 1976, § 2-21) Sec. 2-39. - Rules of order. Robert's Rules of Order, newly revised, 1970 edition, published by Scott, Foresman and Company, shall govern the board of commissioners in its deliberation in cases not otherwise provided for by statute, ordinance, rule or regulation. Sec. 2-40. - Debates. Every member of the board of commissioners desiring to speak shall address the chair, and, upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. (Code 1976, § 2-23) Sec. 2-41. - Interruptions. Once recognized, a member of the board of commissioners shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him to order or as otherwise provided in this article. While speaking, if a member is called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined, and, if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. (Code 1976, § 2-24) Sec. 2-42. - Privilege of closing debate. The commissioner moving the adoption of an ordinance or resolution shall have the privilege of closing the debate. (Code 1976, § 2-25) Sec. 2-43. - Motion to reconsider. A motion to reconsider any action taken by the board of commissioners may be made only on the day such action was taken. Such motion may be made either immediately during the same session, or at a recessed or adjourned session thereof. Such motion must be made by one of the prevailing side, but may be seconded by another member, and may be made at any time and have precedence over all other motions or while a member has the floor, and it shall be debatable. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent any member of the commission from making or remaking the same or any other motion at a subsequent meeting of the board. (Code 1976, § 2-26) Sec. 2-44. - Remarks of commissioners; when entered in minutes. A commissioner may request, through the presiding officer, the privilege of having an abstract of his statement on any subject under consideration by the board of commissioners entered in the minutes. Upon such request, such statement shall be entered in the minutes. (Code 1976, § 2-27) Sec. 2-45. - Synopsis of debate; when entered in minutes. The clerk may be directed by the presiding officer, with the consent of the board of commissioners, to enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the board. (Code 1976, § 2-28) Sec. 2-46. - Addressing the board of commissioners. Any person desiring to address the board of commissioners shall first secure the permission of the presiding officer to do so; provided, however, that, unless the presiding officer rules otherwise, any qualified person may address the board of commissioners, under the following headings of business, without securing such prior permission: (1) Written communications. Interested parties or other authorized representatives may address the board of commissioners by written communications in regard to matters that are under discussion. (2) Oral communications. Taxpayers or residents of the city, or their authorized legal representatives, may address the board of commissioners by oral communication on any matter concerning the city's business or over which the board of commissioners has control; provided, however, that preference shall be given to those persons who have notified the city manager in advance of their desire to speak in order that such persons may appear on the agenda of the board. (3) Reading of protest, etc. Interested persons or their authorized representatives may address the board by the reading of protests, petitions or communications relating to zoning, sewer and street proceedings or similar matters in regard to matters then under consideration. (Code 1976, § 2-29) Sec. 2-47. - Addressing the board of commissioners after motion is made. After a motion is made by the board of commissioners, no person shall address the board without securing permission of the board to do so. (Code 1976, § 2-30) Sec. 2-48. - Manner of addressing board of commissioners; time limit. Each person addressing the board of commissioners shall step up in front of the board; give his name and remarks in an audible tone of voice; and, unless further time is granted by the board, shall limit his address to 15 minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to the board as a body and not to any members thereof. No person, other than the board and the person having the floor, shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, without the permission of the presiding officer, either directly or through a member of the board. No question shall be asked of a board member, except through the presiding officer. (Code 1976, § 2-31) Sec. 2-49. - Silence constitutes affirmative vote. Unless a member of the board of commissioners states that he is not voting, his silence shall be construed and recorded as an affirmative vote. (Code 1976, § 2-32) Sec. 2-50. - Decorum—Generally. (a) By board members. While the board of commissioners is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum, and a member, by conversation or otherwise, shall neither delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the board, nor disturb any member while speaking, or refuse to obey the orders of the board or its presiding officer, except as otherwise provided in this Code. (b) By persons. Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks or who shall become boisterous while addressing the board shall be forthwith barred from further audience before the board by the presiding officer, unless permission to continue is granted by a majority vote of the board. (Code 1976, § 2-33) Sec. 2-51. - Same—Enforcement. The chief of police or the marshal, or such members of the police department as may be designated, shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the board of commissioners' meetings and shall be sergeant-at-arms of the board meetings. Upon instructions of the presiding officer, it shall be the duty of the sergeant-at-arms, or such members of the police department present, to place any person who violates the order and decorum of the meeting under arrest and cause him to be prosecuted under the provisions of this Code, and the complaint is to be signed by the presiding officer. (Code 1976, § 2-34) Sec. 2-52. - Adjournment. A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. (Code 1976, § 2-35) Sec. 2-53. - Special committees. All special committees shall be appointed by the board of commissioners. (Code 1976, § 2-36) Sec. 2-54. - Report of committees. The committees appointed by the board of commissioners shall make such reports as may be necessary, in writing, and shall return the petition, resolution, account or other paper submitted for consideration. (Code 1976, § 2-37) Sec. 2-55. - Members may file protests against board action. Any member of the board of commissioners shall have the right to have the reasons for his dissent from, or protest against, any action of the board entered on the minutes. (Code 1976, § 2-38) Sec. 2-56. - Reports and resolutions to be filed with clerk. All reports and resolutions of the board of commissioners shall be filed with the city clerk and entered upon the minutes in brief form. (Code 1976, § 2-39) Secs. 2-57—2-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LEGISLATION[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Ordinances of city council not to bind succeeding councils, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-3; authority to adopt municipal ordinances, resolutions or regulations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3(a).
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-91. - Preparation of ordinances. All ordinances shall be prepared by the city attorney. No ordinance shall be prepared for presentation to the board of commissioners unless ordered by a member of the board or the city manager, or prepared by the city attorney on his own initiative. (Code 1976, § 2-51) Sec. 2-92. - Ordaining clause. The entering or ordaining clause of all ordinances introduced in board of commissioners shall be: "Be it ordained by the board of commissioners for the City of Jesup:" (Code 1976, § 2-52) Sec. 2-93. - Subject restricted. No ordinance shall relate to more than one subject, except ordinances making appropriations and ordinances codifying or rearranging existing ordinances, and the subject of all ordinances shall be clearly expressed in the title. (Code 1976, § 2-53) Sec. 2-94. - Introduction and sponsorship for passage; exception. Ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects requiring action by the board of commissioners must be introduced and sponsored by a member of the board, except that the city manager or city attorney may present ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects to the commissioners, and any commissioner may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that such ordinances, resolutions, matters or subjects be adopted; otherwise, they shall not be considered. (Code 1976, § 2-54) Sec. 2-95. - Final passage restricted. No ordinance shall be put on its final passage on the same day on which it was introduced unless a second reading is dispensed with by a vote of all members of the board of commissioners. (Code 1976, § 2-55) Sec. 2-96. - When ordinances to take effect. All ordinances passed by the board of commissioners, except when otherwise specifically provided, shall take effect and be in force from and after the last reading. (Code 1976, § 2-56) Sec. 2-97. - Effect of repeal. Sec. 2-121. - Effect. Any and all additions and amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the board of commissioners to make such additions and amendments a part of this Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that reference to "the Code of the City of Jesup," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. (Code 1976, § 2-64) Sec. 2-122. - Manner. All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections, or any part thereof, subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the board of commissioners. (Code 1976, § 2-65) Sec. 2-123. - Language. Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of the City of Jesup, is hereby amended to read as follows:… (set out new provisions in full)." (Code 1976, § 2-66) Sec. 2-124. - New material. (a) If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of the City of Jesup, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article, chapter or other designation, as the case may be), to be numbered _____, which reads as follows:… (set out new provisions in full)." (b) In lieu of subsection (a) of this section, when the board of commissioners desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature embracing a subject not previously existing in the Code which the board desires to incorporate into the Code, a provision, in substantially the following language, may be made part of such ordinance: "It is the intention of the board of commissioners, and it is hereby ordained, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the Code of the City of Jesup, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." (Code 1976, § 2-67) Sec. 2-125. - Repeal. All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number, article number, chapter or other number, as the case may be. (Code 1976, § 2-68) Sec. 2-126. - Subject to general penalty. In case of the amendment of any section of this Code by the board of commissioners for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in section 1-11 of this Code shall apply to the section, as amended; or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the general penalty as provided in section 1-11 of this Code, is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. (Code 1976, § 2-69) Sec. 2-127. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of commissioners. A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the board or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in this Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during that period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be prepared so that when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance," or words of the same meaning, to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. (Code 1976, § 2-127) Secs. 2-128—2-160. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4]

Sec. 2-161. - Chief executive officer and head of administrative branch; powers and duties. The city manager shall be the chief executive officer of the city and head of the administrative branch of the city government. He shall be responsible to the board of commissioners for the proper administration of all affairs of the city and to that end, and subject to the provisions of the Charter of the city, he shall have power and shall be required to: (1) Appoint and remove all officers and employees of the city, except as may otherwise be provided by the Charter of the city and, except that he may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint and remove subordinates in such department or office; (2) Ensure that all laws and ordinances of the city are enforced; (3) Exercise control over all of the departments or divisions of the city; (4) Attend all meetings of the board; (5) Prepare and submit to the board an annual budget, setting out the probable needed expenditures in all departments of the city for the ensuing year, which report shall show, as nearly as can be determined, the probable revenue of the city from all sources; (6) Keep the board advised as to the financial condition and needs of the city; (7) Supervise and direct the conduct of all officers and employees of the city, and supervise the performance of all contracts made by any person for all work done in the city, and make all purchases of materials and supplies used by the city under competitive bids, and under such rules and regulations as the board may prescribe; (8) Appoint, discharge and fix the salaries of employees in all departments. All such appointments shall be made upon merit and fitness for the performance of the duties required; (9) Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the Charter of the city, and such other duties as may be required of him by the board. (Code 1976, § 2-82) Sec. 2-162. - Oaths of office. Each of the following officers and employees of the city shall be required to take an oath of office before entering upon the discharge of his duties, which oath shall be subscribed by the person taking it before the city attorney or any other person authorized to administer oaths and preserved in the office of the city clerk: (1) Officers. The city manager and each officer and department head. (2) Police officers. Every member of the police department, including any private, special, temporary or substitute police officer which the city may appoint. (3) Firefighters. Every member of the fire department who serves on a full-time basis. (Code 1976, § 2-84) Sec. 2-163. - Form of oath for the city manager and officers. Footnotes: --- (6) --- Editor's note— Section 1 of an ordinance adopted July 7, 2015, amended div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 2, §§ 2-221—2-224 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1976 Code, §§ 2-210—2-213.
Sec. 2-221. - Statement of purpose and declaration of need. (a) There exists in the city an essential need for a downtown development authority to revitalize and redevelop the city, to promote trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in the city and to likewise promote the general welfare of the public by creating a climate favorable to the location of new industry, trade and commerce and to foster the further development of existing industry, trade and commerce within the city. (b) The revitalization and redevelopment of the central business district of the City of Jesup is essential to develop and promote for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry, and employment opportunities and promote the general welfare of this city by maintaining a climate favorable to the location of new industry, trade, and commerce and the development of existing industry, trade, and commerce within the city. (c) It is, therefore, in the public interest and is vital to the public welfare of the people of this city, and it is declared to be the public purpose of this division, so to revitalize and redevelop the central business districts of the City of Jesup. (d) Likewise, the continued revitalization and redevelopment of the city is in the public interest and vital to the public welfare. Therefore, be it known to all persons that the public purpose of this division is to protect and serve the public interest and the public welfare through the redevelopment and revitalization of the city. (e) The city has previously created and activated the Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia under that resolution activating the Downtown Development Authority of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup, Georgia dated November 20, 1984. The purpose of this division is to restate the provisions governing the said Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-222. - Intent and objective. It is the intent and objective of this division to continue and perpetuate the Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia, to authorize it to carry out the full range of its powers as provided by the Downtown Development Authorities Law of 1981, as amended, and to promote the Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia in fulfilling its purposes as stated in such law. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-223. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, or in the alternative if so defined therein shall have the same meaning as set forth in the O.C.G.A. § 36-42-3, as amended from time to time, should those definitions differ. Cost of the project or cost of any project means and includes: (1) All costs of acquisition (by purchase or otherwise), construction, assembly, installation, modification, renovation, or rehabilitation incurred in connection with any project or any part of any project; (2) All costs of real property, fixtures, or personal property used in or in connection with or necessary for any project or for any facilities related thereto, including, but not limited to, the cost of all land, estates for years, easements, rights, improvements, water rights, connections for utility services, fees, franchises, permits, approvals, licenses, and certificates; the cost of securing any such franchises, permits, approvals, licenses, or certificates; and the cost of preparation of any application therefor and the cost of all fixtures, machinery, equipment, furniture, and other property used in or in connection with or necessary for any project; (3) All financing charges and loan fees and all interest on revenue bonds, notes, or other obligations of the downtown development authority which accrues or is paid prior to and during the period of construction of a project and during such additional period as the authority may reasonably determine to be necessary to place such project in operation; (4) All costs of engineering, surveying, and architectural and legal services and all expenses incurred by engineers, surveyors, architects, and attorneys in connection with any project; (5) All expenses for inspection of any project; (6) All fees of fiscal agents, paying agents, and trustees for bondholders under any trust agreement, indenture of trust, or similar instrument or agreement; all expenses incurred by any such fiscal agents, paying agents, and trustees; and all other costs and expenses incurred relative to the issuance of any revenue bonds, notes, or other obligations for any project; (7) All fees of any type charged by the downtown development authority in connection with any project; (8) All expenses of or incidental to determining the feasibility or practicability of any project; (9) All costs of plans and specifications for any project; (10) All costs of title insurance and examinations of title with respect to any project; (11) Repayment of any loans made for the advance payment of any part of any of the foregoing costs, including interest thereon and any other expenses of such loans; (12) Administrative expenses of the downtown development authority and such other expenses as may be necessary or incidental to any project or the financing thereof or the placing of any project in operation; and (13) The establishment of a fund or funds for the creation of a debt service reserve, a renewal and replacement reserve, or such other funds or reserves as the downtown development authority may approve with respect to the financing and operation of any project and as may be authorized by any bond resolution, trust agreement, indenture of trust, or similar instrument or agreement pursuant to the provisions of which the issuance of any revenue bonds, notes, or other obligations of the downtown development authority may be authorized. (14) Any cost, obligation, or expense incurred for any of the foregoing purposes shall be a part of the cost of the project and may be paid or reimbursed as such out of proceeds of revenue bonds, notes, or other obligations issued by the downtown development authority. Downtown development area means the geographical area within the City of Jesup designated as such by the resolution of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup as modified by any subsequent resolution of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup. Project means: (1) The acquisition, construction, installation, modification, renovation, or rehabilitation of land, interests in land, buildings, structures, facilities, or other improvements located or to be located within the downtown development area, and the acquisition, installation, modification, renovation, rehabilitation, or furnishing of fixtures, machinery, equipment, furniture, or other property of any nature whatsoever used on, in, or in connection with any such land, interest in land, building, structure, facility, or other improvement, all for the essential public purpose of the development of trade, commerce, industry, and employment opportunities in its authorized area of operation; and (2) The provision of financing to property owners for the purpose of installing or modifying improvements to their property in order to reduce the energy or water consumption on such property or to install an improvement to such property that produces energy from renewable resources. (3) A project may be for any industrial, commercial, business, office, parking, public, or other use, provided that a majority of the directors of the downtown development authority determine, by a duly adopted resolution, that the project and such use thereof would further the public purpose of this division. Such term shall include any one or more buildings or structures used or to be used as a not-for-profit hospital, not-for-profit skilled nursing home, or not-for-profit intermediate care home subject to regulation and licensure by the department of community health and all necessary, convenient, or related interests in land, machinery, apparatus, appliances, equipment, furnishings, appurtenances, site preparation, landscaping, and physical amenities. Revenue bonds or bonds means any bonds of the downtown development authority, which are authorized to be issued under the Constitution and laws of Georgia, including refunding bonds but not including notes or other obligations of the downtown development authority. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-224. - Powers. The Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia shall have those powers, and fulfill those duties, as created, imposed and existing under the Downtown Development Authorities Law of 1981, as amended. In addition thereto, the Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia shall have the following additional powers: (1) To sue and be sued; (2) To adopt and amend a corporate seal; (3) To make and execute contracts and other instruments necessary to exercise the powers of the authority, any of which contracts may be made with the county or may be made with any one or more municipal corporations in the county, and the county and all municipal corporations therein are hereby authorized to enter into contracts with the authority; (4) To receive and administer gifts, grants and devises of any property and to administer trusts; (5) To acquire by purchase, gift or construction any real or personal property desired to be acquired as part of any project or for the purpose of improving, extending, adding to, reconstructing, renovating or remodeling any project or part thereof already acquired, or for the purpose of demolition to make room for such project or any part thereof; (6) To sell, lease, exchange, transfer, assign, pledge, mortgage or dispose of, or grant options for any such purposes, any real or personal property or interest therein; (7) To mortgage, convey, pledge or assign any properties, revenues, income, tolls, charges or fees owned or received by the authority; (8) To appoint officers and retain agents, engineers, attorneys, fiscal agents, accountants and employees and to provide for their compensation and duties; (9) To extend credit or make loans to any person including any industrial entity, for the planning, design, construction, acquisition or carrying out of any project, which credit or loans shall be secured by loan agreements, mortgages, security agreements, contracts and all other instruments or fees or charges, upon such terms and conditions as the authority shall determine reasonable in connection with such loans, including provision for the establishment and maintenance of reserves and insurance funds, and in the exercise of powers granted by this section in connection with a project for the person to require the inclusion in any contract, loan agreement, security agreement or other instrument, such provisions for guaranty, insurance, construction, use, operation, maintenance and financing of a project as the authority may deem necessary or desirable; (10) To acquire, accept or retain equitable interests, security interests or other interests in any property, real or personal, by mortgage, assignment, security agreement, pledge, conveyance, contract, lien, loan agreement or other consensual transfer in order to secure the repayment of any monies loaned or credit extended by the authority; (11) To construct, acquire, own, repair, remodel, maintain, extend, improve and equip projects located on land owned or leased by the authority or land owned or leased by others and to pay all or part of the cost of any such project from the proceeds of revenue bonds of the authority or from any contribution or loans by persons or any other contribution, all of which the authority is hereby authorized to receive and accept and use; (12) To borrow money and issue its revenue bonds and bond anticipation notes from time to time and use the proceeds thereof for the purpose of paying all or part of the cost of any project, including the cost of extending, adding to or improving such project, or for the purpose of refunding any such bonds of the authority theretofore issued, and to otherwise carry out the purposes of this chapter and to pay all other costs of the authority incident to, or necessary and appropriate to, such purposes, including the providing of funds to be paid into any funds to secure such bonds and notes; provided that all bonds and notes shall be issued in accordance with the procedures and subject to the limitations set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-62-8; (13) As security for repayment of authority obligations, to pledge, mortgage, convey, assign, hypothecate or otherwise encumber any property, real or personal, of the authority and to execute any trust agreement, indenture or security agreement containing any provisions not in conflict with law, which trust agreement, indenture or security agreement may provide for foreclosure or forced sale of any property of the authority upon default on the obligations either in payment of principal or interest or in the performance of any term or condition contained in the agreement or indenture; the state on behalf of itself and each county, municipal corporation, political subdivision or taxing district therein hereby waives any right it or county, municipal corporation, political subdivision or taxing district may have to prevent the forced sale or foreclosure of any property of the authority so mortgaged or encumbered, and any such mortgage or encumbrance may be foreclosed in accordance with law and the terms thereof; (14) Any authority authorizing an air transportation facility is empowered to contract with any county or municipality in the state, and any county or municipality in the state is empowered to contract with any authority to furnish air transportation services where such service is not otherwise in existence; and (15) To do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers expressly conferred above. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-225. - Directors. The board of directors of the downtown development authority shall consist of seven directors. (1) Directors shall be: a. Taxpayers residing in the municipal corporation for which the authority is created; b. Owners or operators of businesses located within the downtown development area and who shall be taxpayers residing in the county in which is located the municipal corporation for which the authority is created; or c. Persons having a combination of the qualifications specified in paragraphs a. and b. of this subsection; d. Provided, however, that one of such directors may be a member of the governing body of the municipal corporation. (2) Not less than four of the directors having the qualifications specified in subsection (1) of this section shall be persons who, in the judgment of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup, either have or represent a party who has an economic interest in the redevelopment and revitalization of the downtown development area. (3) Notwithstanding subsection (1) of this section, one director appointed to the board may reside outside the county; provided, however, that such appointed director owns a business within the downtown development area and is a resident of the State of Georgia. If subsequently to his or her appointment to the board pursuant to this subsection, the director ceases to own a business within the downtown development area or reside in the State of Georgia, such director shall relinquish his or her seat on the board. (4) Successors to the directors shall be appointed by the governing body of the municipal corporation. (5) Terms. The directors of the downtown development authority shall serve for a term of office for four years. The term of a director who is also a member of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup shall also end when such director is no longer a member of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup. If at the end of any term of office of any director a successor to such director has not been appointed, the director whose term of office has expired shall continue to hold office until a successor is appointed. Said four-year terms shall coincide, and run parallel with, the regular terms of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup. (6) Training requirements. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-42-7, any director of the downtown development authority, except for a director who is also a member of the Commissioners of the City of Jesup, shall attend and complete at least eight hours of training on development and redevelopment programs within the first 12 months of the director's appointment to the downtown development authority. (7) Removal from office. The death of a director, physical or mental disability of a director preventing his or her service as a director, or the disqualification from service, by operation of law or otherwise, of any director shall automatically result in said director's immediate removal. (8) Appointment of officers. The directors shall elect one of their members as chairman and another as vice chairman and shall also elect a secretary and a treasurer or a secretary-treasurer, either of whom may but need not be a director. Officers shall remain in such designated post until such post is filled or reappointed by the membership. (9) Quorum. A simple majority of the board of directors of the downtown development authority shall constitute a quorum. However, no action shall be taken by the Downtown Development Authority of Jesup, Georgia without the affirmative vote of a majority of the full directorship of the board. (10) Faithful execution of duties required. The directors shall faithfully carry out their duties in an exemplary manner and abide by all laws and regulations binding on the downtown development authority and its members. (11) Compensation and expense reimbursement. The directors shall receive no compensation for their services but shall be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. (12) Bylaws, operating procedures and long range plans. The directors appointed according to this division shall, at the earliest possible time, ensure that a set of bylaws, operating procedures and long range plans of development have been developed and adopted. (13) Publication of reports. The directors appointed according to this division shall cause to be published both interim and annual reports of the downtown development authority's activities, plans and accomplishments. (14) Provision of annual audit. The directors appointed according to this division shall annually employ an independent certified public accountant to perform and publish an audit of financial transactions and the financial position of the downtown development authority. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-226. - Boundaries of the central business district. (a) The boundaries of the authority's district shall be redefined as follows: For a point of beginning , commencing at the intersection of United States Highway 84 (Georgia State Route 38 or also known as South First Street) and West Pine Street; and thence, from said point of beginning proceeding east by southeast along West Pine Street to its intersection with Northeast Brunswick Street; and thence from said intersection proceeding generally south by southwest along Brunswick Street to its intersection with East Orange Street; and thence from said intersection, proceeding generally west by northwest along Orange Street to its intersection with United States Highway 84 (Georgia State Route 38 or also known as South First Street); and thence from said intersection returning then north by northeast along United States Highway 84 (Georgia State Route 38 or also known as South First Street) to its intersection with West Pine Street, which is the point of beginning . (b) The Commissioners of the City of Jesup shall have, and solely retain, the authority to redefine the boundaries of the authority's district from time to time. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-227. - City of Jesup not bound. The downtown development authority shall have no power or authority to bind the City of Jesup by any contract, agreement, financial obligation, indebtedness, or otherwise; and no contract, agreement, financial obligation, or indebtedness incurred by the downtown development authority shall ever be a claim or charge against the City of Jesup, provided that both the downtown development authority and the City of Jesup shall be bound to each other by contracts, agreements, financial obligations or indebtedness between themselves. (Ord. of 7-7-2015(1), § 1) Sec. 2-228. - Dissolution. Should the downtown development authority for any reason be dissolved, title to all property of any kind and nature, real and personal, held by the joint board at the time of such dissolution shall be conveyed to the City of Jesup; or title to any such property may be conveyed prior to such dissolution in accordance with provisions which may be made therefor in any resolution or trust instrument relating to such property, subject to any liens, leases, or other encumbrances outstanding against or in respect to such property at the time of such conveyance. Sec. 2-231. - Short title. This division will be known and may be cited as the "Joint Board of Tourism for the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County Act." (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 1) Sec. 2-232. - Definitions and references. As used in this division, the term: Cities means the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven, which are bodies public and politic in Wayne County, Georgia. Conventions means that term as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. County means Wayne County, Georgia. Joint board means the new joint board of tourism for the Cities of Jesup, Screven, and Odum and Wayne County that is created hereunder. Special events means events which, in the judgment of the joint board, will promote tourism in the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County, Georgia. Tourism means that term as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. Trade show means that term as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 2) Sec 2-233. - Creation of joint board; status, tax exemption, and sovereign immunity. (a) There is hereby created a new body public and politic to be known as the Joint Board of Tourism for the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County (hereinafter in this division also referred to as the "joint board"). The joint board is intended to be an agency and instrumentality of the City of Jesup and Wayne County and a governmental unit for purposes of Sections 103, 141 and 150 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and, is intended to be a subordinated entity to the City of Jesup and Wayne County to the extent necessary under Section 265(b)(3)(E)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. (b) The joint board shall have its principal office in the geographical limits of the City of Jesup, as amended from time to time, and its legal situs or domiciliary for the purposes of this division shall be the said geographical limits of the City of Jesup. (c) The exercise of the powers conferred upon the joint board in this division shall constitute essential governmental functions for public purposes. The properties of the joint board, both real and personal, and the income of the joint board are declared to be public properties and income used for the benefit and welfare of the people of the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County, and not for the purpose of private or corporate benefit, and such properties, to the extent of the joint board's ownership thereof or other interest therein, and all income and obligations of the joint board shall be exempt from all taxes and special assessments of the State of Georgia or any city, county, or other political subdivision thereof. The joint board shall have all of the exemptions and exclusions from taxes as are now granted to cities and counties in the State of Georgia for the operation of properties or facilities similar to the properties and facilities to be owned or operated, or both, by the joint board. (d) Any action to protect or enforce any rights under the provisions of this division or any suit or action against the joint board shall be brought in the Superior Court of Wayne County, Georgia. (e) The property of the joint board shall not be subject to levy and sale under legal process. (f) The records of the joint board shall be public records which are subject to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. (g) Nothing in this division shall be construed to abridge or change the powers and duties of other authorities, departments, boards, and like agencies of Wayne County, Georgia or the Cities of Jesup, Odum or Screven. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 3) Sec. 2-234. - Members and meetings. (a) The joint board shall consist of eight appointed members, who shall serve terms of four years. (1) Three members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of Wayne County, Georgia. (2) Three members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the City of Jesup, Georgia. (3) One member shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the City of Odum, which such member shall be a resident of the City of Odum. (4) One member shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the City of Screven, which such member shall be a resident of the City of Screven. (5) The city manager of the City of Jesup and the county administrator of Wayne County, Georgia shall be ex officio, nonvoting members of the joint board. (b) The initial term of the members of the joint board shall end on December 31, 2016. (c) Appointments for succeeding terms shall be made in January of the calendar year following expiration of terms with said appointments before effective thereupon. (d) Any member may resign at any time by filing a written notice of resignation with the joint board. (e) The joint board shall meet at such times as may be necessary to transact the business coming before it. Meetings shall be conducted in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order. (f) At the first meeting of the joint board, the members shall elect a chairperson, a vice-chairperson, and a secretary-treasurer from its membership. Thereafter, commencing in the year 2014, at the first meeting of the joint board and each calendar year thereafter, the members shall elect a chairperson, a vice-chairperson, and a secretary-treasurer from its membership for that calendar year. The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the joint board. The vice-chairperson shall preside at meetings in the absence of the chairperson. In the absence of both the chairperson and vice-chairperson, the members present at a meeting shall elect a temporary chairperson to preside at that meeting so long as the chairperson and vice-chairperson both remain absent from the meeting. (g) The joint board shall have the right to elect or hire the chief executive officer or program coordinator of the joint board, to set the salary or wages of such person, to pay a salary or wages to such person, and to otherwise set the terms and conditions of the employment of such person. (h) Four members shall constitute a quorum. Official action may be taken by majority vote of those members voting on a matter if a quorum is present and voting on such matter, except that the bylaws of the joint board may only be initially adopted or subsequently amended by majority vote of all members. All members present at a meeting, including the chairperson, vice-chairperson or any other member presiding at such meeting, shall be entitled to vote on all matters that come before the meeting. No vacancy on the joint board shall impair the right of the quorum to exercise all the rights and perform all the duties of the joint board. (i) Members shall receive no compensation for their services as members of the joint board, but may be reimbursed for their proper and reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, subject to any limitations imposed by general law of the State of Georgia on the reimbursement of public officials and subject to any limitations which may be contained from time to time in the bylaws of the joint board. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 4) Sec. 2-235. - Purpose. The purpose of the joint board is to plan, coordinate, and administer an effective tourism program for Wayne County and the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven in such manner as the joint board shall determine to be appropriate. All proceeds of the hotel-motel tax excise tax collected by the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County, which are provided to the joint board, shall be expended in compliance with the applicable provisions of state law, inclusive of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51, as amended. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 5) Sec. 2-236. - Powers. (a) The joint board shall have all powers allowed by law and consistent with the provisions of this division as are necessary or convenient to carry out its corporate purpose, including, without limitation, the power to: (1) Adopt and alter a corporate seal. (2) Purchase advertising promoting tourism, conventions, trade shows, and special events. (3) Encourage, solicit, promote, procure, sponsor, co-sponsor, and service conventions, trade shows and special events. (4) Conduct activities to foster better public understanding on the part of individuals and businesses of the importance of tourism and the convention and visitors industry to the economy of Wayne County and the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven. (5) Conduct activities to encourage and assist the cooperation between the businesses and industries servicing tourists, conventions, and special events. (6) Engage in fundraising activities in furtherance of its corporate purpose. (7) Acquire by purchase, lease, or otherwise and to hold, lease, and dispose of real and personal property of every kind and character for its corporate purposes. (8) Acquire in its own name by purchase, on such terms and conditions and in such manner as it may deem proper, real property or rights of easements therein or franchises necessary or convenient for its corporate purpose, to use the same so long as its corporate existence shall continue, to lease or make contracts with respect to the use of the same, or to dispose of the same in any manner it deems to the best advantage of the joint board. (9) Appoint, select, and employ a chief executive officer, program director, officers, agents, and employees, and independent consultants including but not limited to engineering, architectural, and construction experts, fiscal agents, economists, and attorneys and fix their respective compensations; and to delegate to the chief executive officer the authority and responsibility necessary to administer properly the day-to-day business of the joint board within policies set by the joint board and subject to its review. The powers delegated to the chief executive officer may, at the election of the joint board, include the making of recommendations as to the hiring and termination of other employees and their compensation, the management of the joint board's offices and properties, the making of budget recommendations, and the hiring of independent consultants. (10) Appoint an advisory committee and other committees of persons from the public and private sectors without regard to their place of residence. (11) To make contracts of every kind and character, and, without limitation, and, without limiting the generality of the above, the joint board shall be permitted to enter into the following: a. Contracts under which hotel-motel taxes collected by the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County are paid to and expended by the joint board as contemplated by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b). b. Contracts under which the joint board purchases administrative and financial management services from the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven and Wayne County to be performed by personnel at the cost of such governmental entity, which shall include the costs of payroll, employee benefits, supplies, and overhead reasonably allocable to the performance of such services. c. Lease contracts relating to leases of real property, personal property, or both real and personal property. (12) Accept loans and grants of money or materials or property of any kind from the United States of America or any agency or instrumentality thereof, upon such terms and conditions as the United States of America or such agency or instrumentality may impose. (13) Accept loans and grants of money or materials or property of any kind from the State of Georgia or any agency or instrumentality or political division thereof, upon such terms and conditions as the State of Georgia or such agency or instrumentality or political subdivision may impose. (14) Sell, lease, grant, exchange, or otherwise dispose of any property, both real and personal, or interest therein. (15) Sue and be sued in contract and in tort and to complain and defend in all courts. (16) Advise and recommend plans to other public and private sector entities for the promotion of tourism, conventions, and trade shows. (17) Conduct studies and develop plans for improving tourism in Wayne County and the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven. (18) Receive and disburse public funds appropriated by Wayne County and the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven, including but not limited to revenues derived from the hotel-motel excise tax collected by them; and to receive and disburse funds from private sources and other revenues which may be received from time to time which would assist in the accomplishment of its corporate purpose. (19) Do all things necessary or convenient to accomplish its corporate purpose and to exercise any power permitted by the laws of the state to be exercised by private corporations which will further the joint board's ability to accomplish such purpose, so long as the exercise of such power is not in conflict with the Constitution or laws of this state. (b) The powers enumerated in each paragraph of subsection (a) of this section are cumulative of and in addition to those powers enumerated in the other paragraphs of subsection (a) of this section and any other powers elsewhere in this division or which may reasonably be inferred from the provisions of this division. This division shall be liberally construed to affect the described purposes, and in interpreting this division, the courts are not to apply "Dillon's Rule." (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 6) Sec. 2-237. - Finances. The joint board shall submit quarterly financial statements to the board of commissioners of Wayne County and the board of commissioners of the City of Jesup. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 7) Sec. 2-238. - Bylaws. The joint board may, by affirmative vote of a majority of all members, adopt bylaws to govern the joint board, its employees, and operation and may by affirmative vote of all members repeal, replace, or amend such bylaws. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 8) Sec. 2-239. - Liability limited. Neither the members of the joint board nor any person executing bonds, notes, leases, or other agreements or obligations on behalf of the joint board shall be personally liable thereon by reason of such execution. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 9) Sec. 2-240. - Cities and Wayne County not bound. The joint board shall have no power or authority to bind Wayne County or the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven by any contract, agreement, financial obligation, indebtedness, or otherwise; and no contract, agreement, financial obligation, or indebtedness incurred by the joint board shall ever be a claim or charge against the Wayne County or the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven, provided that both the joint board and Wayne County or the Cities of Jesup, Odum and Screven shall be bound to each other by contracts, agreements, financial obligations or indebtedness between themselves. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 10) Sec. 2-241. - Dissolution. Should the joint board for any reason be dissolved, title to all property of any kind and nature, real and personal, held by the joint board at the time of such dissolution shall be conveyed to the Wayne County, Georgia and the City of Jesup jointly; or title to any such property may be conveyed prior to such dissolution in accordance with provisions which may be made therefor in any resolution or trust instrument relating to such property, subject to any liens, leases, or other encumbrances outstanding against or in respect to such property at the time of such conveyance. (Ord. of 1-15-2013, § 11) Secs. 2-242—2-250. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - CODE OF ETHICS FOR CITY OFFICIALS
Sec. 2-251. - Declaration of policy. It is the policy of the city that the proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that governmental decisions and policies be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, a code of ethics for all city officials is adopted. (Ord. of 2-6-2001, § 2-222) Sec. 2-252. - Purposes; exemptions. (a) The purpose of the code of ethics set forth in this article is to: (1) Encourage high ethical standards in official conduct by city employees and officials. (2) Establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth the acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interest of the city. (3) Require disclosure by such officials of private financial or other interest in manners that affect the city. (4) Serve as a basis for disciplining those who refuse to abide by its terms. (b) The provisions of this article shall not apply to political contributions, loans, expenditures, reports or regulation of political campaigns or the conduct of candidates in such campaigns. (Ord. of 2-6-2001, § 2-222) Sec. 2-253. - Applicability. All commissions, boards or authorities established by the provisions of the code of ethics set forth in this article shall be applicable to all members of the board of commissioners and employees. (Ord. of 2-6-2001, § 2-223) Sec. 2-254. - Definitions.
