If any licensee should fail to maintain any junkyard in accordance with the standards of this article, the board of commissioners shall cause notice to be served upon such licensee, requiring him to remedy any default within a reasonable length of time, but not more than 30 days, upon failure of which, the board of commissioners shall revoke the license previously issued. (Code 1976, § 16-21) Secs. 22-65—22-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Noise control for hawkers, peddlers and vendors, § 38-114; streets and sidewalks, ch. 86. State Law reference— Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; exception from local peddler or itinerant vendor licensing requirements for persons selling agricultural products, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6; Transient Merchant Act of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Peddler means any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, house to house or street to street, for the sale of, as well as the selling, offering for sale or taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of, goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether or not he is collecting advance payments on such sales, provided that this definition shall include any person who, for himself or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. The term "peddler" shall include the term "canvasser," "transient or itinerant merchant or vendor" or "transient or itinerant photographer." (Code 1976, § 22-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-102. - Exceptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: (1) Solicitations, sales or distributions made by charitable, educational or religious organizations which have their principal place of activity in the city. (2) The sale or solicitation of orders for the sale of milk, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, eggs and other farm and garden produce grown or produced by the person selling such items. (3) The sale or introduction into the city of any agricultural products raised in the state, including swine, cattle, sheep, goats and poultry, and the products thereof, and any unprocessed seafood, where the sale of such products is made within 90 days of the introduction of such products into the city. (4) A traveling salesman engaged in taking orders for the sale of goods where no delivery of goods is made at the time of taking such order. (5) A merchant or dealer, the site of whose business is elsewhere, who delivers goods to either wholesale or retail customers in the city on orders previously taken by his salesmen or on orders previously given directly to him by such wholesale or retail customers. (6) The employees of any merchant or dealer doing business in the city in a manner defined by subsection (5) of this section, who are engaged in the delivery of such goods to either wholesale or retail customers. (7) Any individual, firm, corporation or other entity otherwise engaged in the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, supplies or other personal property to any person being in business within the city, as defined in section 90-41 of this Code, provided, such items sold are for use by such person in his business or are for resale by such person. (Code 1976, § 22-2) Sec. 22-103. - Entrance to premises restricted. It shall be unlawful for any peddler to enter upon any private premises when such premises are posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed," "No Solicitations Allowed" or other words to such effect. (Code 1976, § 22-3) Sec. 22-104. - Refusal to leave. Any peddler who enters upon a premises owned, leased or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises or his agent to leave and not return to such premises, shall be deemed guilty of an offense. (Code 1976, § 22-4) Sec. 22-105. - Misrepresentation. It shall be unlawful for any peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the goods, wares, merchandise or services. (Code 1976, § 22-5) Sec. 22-106. - Hours of operation. It shall be unlawful for any peddler to engage in the business of peddling within the city between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and 9:00 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with, or invitation from, the prospective customer. (Code 1976, § 22-6) Secs. 22-107—22-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 22-131. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a peddler within the city without first obtaining a permit to do so. (Code 1976, § 22-18) Sec. 22-132. - Application. Applicants for a permit under this division shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: (1) The name and a description of the applicant; (2) The permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; (3) A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; (4) If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; (5) The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; (6) The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed and the proposed method of delivery; (7) A photograph of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; (8) A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, offense or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; (9) Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery; (10) The last five municipalities wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city; and (11) Such other relevant information as may be required by the investigation of the applicant. (Code 1976, § 22-19) Sec. 22-133. - Driver's license. At the time of filing his application for a permit required by this division, the applicant shall present his driver's license, if he has one, to the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 22-20) Sec. 22-134. - Application fee. At the time of filing the permit application, a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated in the application. (Code 1976, § 22-21) Sec. 22-135. - False or misleading information. It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading information in connection with his application for a permit required by this division. (Code 1976, § 22-22) Sec. 22-136. - Fingerprints. At the time of making application for a permit required by this division, the applicant shall submit to fingerprinting by the chief of police. (Code 1976, § 22-23) Sec. 22-137. - Permit fee. Before any peddler's permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant shall pay fee of $300.00. The permit shall be valid for 30 days, after which, the permit shall expire. (Code 1976, § 22-24; Ord. of 3-17-2009) Sec. 22-138. - Bond. (a) Every applicant who is not a resident of the city, or who is a resident of the city and represents a firm whose principal place of business is located outside the state, shall file a surety bond with the city clerk, running to the city, in the amount of $1,000.00, with surety acceptable to and approved by the city clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall fully comply with all of the applicable provisions of this Code, the ordinances of the city and state law regulating and concerning the business of peddling and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the peddler, and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with such peddler that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of such peddler. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. (b) If the applicant is an agent, employee, canvasser or solicitor of a corporation authorized to do business in the state or registered under the fictitious name act of the state, such corporation or fictitious name business may furnish one bond in the amount of $1,000.00 for any and all of its agents, employees, canvassers or solicitors. (Code 1976, § 22-25) Sec. 22-139. - Service of process. Before any permit shall be issued under this division, there shall also be filed with the city clerk an instrument in writing, signed by the applicant under oath, nominating and appointing the city clerk as his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on the behalf of such applicant, and service of a summons in any action brought upon the applicant's bond shall be deemed made when served on the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 22-26) Sec. 22-140. - Investigation. Upon receipt of an application for a permit required by this division, the original of such application shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. The chief of police shall complete his investigation within one week of receiving the permit application. (Code 1976, § 22-27) Sec. 22-141. - Denial. If, as a result of the investigation as required by section 22-140, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the permit application his disapproval and his reasons for such disapproval, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit shall be issued. (Code 1976, § 22-28) Sec. 22-142. - Issuance. If, as a result of the investigation as required by section 22-140, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse his approval on the application, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return the permit along with the application to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the required fee, deliver the permit to the applicant. (Code 1976, § 22-29) Sec. 22-143. - Contents. Each permit issued under this division shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name and address of the permittee, the class of permit issued, the date of issuance and the length of time the permit shall be operative, as well as the permit number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such business. (Code 1976, § 22-30) Sec. 22-144. - Record. The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued under this division. (Code 1976, § 22-31) Sec. 22-145. - Display. Every peddler having a permit issued under the provisions of this division and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon request of any person, and failure to do so shall be deemed an offense. (Code 1976, § 22-32) Sec. 22-146. - Duration. Every permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be valid for the period of time stated in such permit, but in no event shall any such permit be issued for a period of time in excess of 12 months. (Code 1976, § 22-33) Sec. 22-147. - Revocation. Any permit issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked by the board of commissioners for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation. (Code 1976, § 22-34) Secs. 22-148—22-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SOLICITORS[4] Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 86. State Law reference— Georgia Charitable Solicitations Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; exception from local peddler or itinerant vendor licensing requirements for persons selling agricultural products, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6; Transient Merchant Act of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-181. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Board means the solicitations advisory board provided for by the provisions of this article. Charitable has its usual meaning, including the terms "patriotic," "philanthropic," "social service," "benevolent," "educational," "civic" or "fraternal," either actual or purported. Contribution has its usual meaning, including alms, food, clothing, money, subscriptions, property or donations under the guise of a loan of money or property. Director means the director of solicitations. Local means a resident of Jesup County or Wayne County when referring to an individual, and one having its principal place of business and/or principal existence in Jesup or Wayne County when referring to a corporation, company, organization or society. Promoter means any person who promotes, manages, supervises, organizes or attempts to promote, manage, supervise or organize a campaign of solicitations. Religious and religion have their commonly accepted definitions, excluding the term "charitable," as defined in this section. Solicit and solicitation mean the request, directly or indirectly, of money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value will be used for a charitable or religious purpose, as defined in this section. Such terms shall also mean and include the following methods of securing money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable or religious purpose, as defined in this section: (1) Any oral or written request. (2) The distribution, circulation, mailing, posting or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement or publication. (3) The making of any announcement to the press over the radio, by telephone or telegraph, concerning an appeal, assemblage, athletic or sports event, bazaar, benefit, campaign, contest, drive, entertainment, exhibition, exposition, party, performance, picnic, sale or social gathering, which the public is requested to patronize or to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable or religious purpose connected with such event. (4) The sale, offer or attempt to sell of any advertisement space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable or religious purpose, or where the name of any charitable or religious person is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale any statement is made that the whole, or any part of, the proceeds from any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale any statement is made that the whole, or any part of, the proceeds from any such sale will go or be donated to any charitable or religious purpose. A solicitation shall be deemed to be complete when it is made, whether or not the person making the solicitation receives any contribution or makes any sale referred to in this definition. To sell and to solicit mean an offer to sell goods, services or merchandise in either of the following methods: (1) Person to person contact on the public streets, highways, parks or other public areas within the city limits; (2) Door to door contact within the city; (3) Contact by telephone within the city. (Code 1976, §§ 30-1, 30-19) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-182. - Use of fictitious name. No person shall, directly or indirectly, solicit contributions for any purpose by misrepresentation of his name, occupation, financial condition, social condition or residence, and no person shall make or perpetrate any other misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation or contribution for any purpose within the city, or in any application or report filed under this article. (Code 1976, § 30-2) Secs. 22-183—22-200. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 22-201. - Required. (a) No local person shall solicit contributions within the city without a permit from the director authorizing such solicitations; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any established local persons organized and operating exclusively for religious or charitable purposes and not operated for the pecuniary profit of any local person if the solicitations by such established local person are conducted among the members thereof, by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for the making of such solicitations, or if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or services of any such established local person; provided, further, that the provisions of this section should not apply to any local farmers in the sale of their crops, stock, animals or other items produced on their farms. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person who is otherwise authorized by law under ordinances of the city, and who does not come within the purview of subsection (a) of this section, to engage in the sale and/or solicitation of orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise or in the solicitation of subscription contracts to magazines, newspapers, books or periodicals without first obtaining a permit therefor as provided in this division. (Code 1976, § 30-14) Sec. 22-202. - Application. Each individual desiring a permit under this division shall complete an application for such permit provided by the office of the director of solicitations in the city, which application shall be in a form and shall provide the following information, and any other information needed for a complete and thorough investigation of the applicant: (1) The name and address or headquarters of the person applying for such permit; (2) The purpose of the solicitations; (3) The name and address of the persons who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitations, and the names of all promoters connected, or to be connected, with the proposed solicitations; (4) An outline of the methods to be used in conducting the solicitations; (5) The time when such solicitations shall be made, giving the preferred dates for the beginning and ending of such solicitations; (6) The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments to be expended or paid to any person in connection with such solicitations, and the names and addresses of all such persons; (7) A full statement of the character and extent of the charitable work being done by the applicant within the city; (8) Such other information as may be reasonably necessary and required by the director of solicitations in order for him and his committee to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitations and whether such solicitations are in the interest of, and not inimical to, the public welfare. (Code 1976, § 30-15) Sec. 22-203. - Investigation of applications. The director of solicitations shall examine all applications filed under this division and shall make, or cause to be made, such further investigation as he deems necessary for him to perform his duties under this article. Upon request by the director, any applicant shall make available for inspection, at any reasonable time, by the director, or any person designated by the director as his representative, all of the applicant's books, records and papers. (Code 1976, § 30-16) Sec. 22-204. - Standards for issuance; fee; renewal. (a) The director of solicitations for the city shall issue a permit under this division, which the city manager must cosign, if the information furnished to him, and other evidence introduced before him, shows that the: (1) Statements contained in the application are true; (2) Applicant is the bona fide agent in good standing of a reputable person engaged in the business of manufacturing, selling or distributing such goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale through such solicitor or peddler; (3) Applicant is the bona fide agent in good standing of a person engaged in the business of selling or distributing any such magazines, newspapers, books or periodicals; or (4) Applicant is engaged in the bona fide sale of goods, wares and merchandise to be offered by him for sale; except no such permit shall be issued to any agent or employee until a letter verifying such agent's or employee's relationship is received, by United States mail, directly from the principal or employer of the applicant and the report on the applicant's fingerprints is received from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the state bureau of investigation; and provided, however, no such permit shall be issued to any applicant until the expiration of a period of ten days from the date the application is filed. (b) A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk shall be paid by the applicant at the time his application for a permit is filed, which sum shall be used to defray the expenses to the city for furnishing the application, making investigation, photographing, fingerprinting and all other expenses incurred in the administration of this article. (c) The permit may be renewed in the following year, provided that the applicant works for the same company and has met all requirements provided by this division. The renewal fee for the permit will be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 30-17) Sec. 22-205. - Appeal from denial. If the director of solicitations should determine that any permit application should be denied, the applicant may file an appeal from such decision with the solicitations advisory board. Such appeal shall be in writing, setting forth the grounds of the appeal and such other matters as the applicant shall desire. Such appeal shall be determined by the solicitations advisory board within ten days after the appeal has been filed, the majority governing, and the decision of the solicitations advisory board shall be final. (Code 1976, § 30-18) Sec. 22-206. - Exception. Any person peddling or soliciting under the terms of this article who holds a valid current license from a state agency authorizing such peddling and solicitations, and which state agency regulated such person licensed by it, is hereby excepted from the provisions of this division. (Code 1976, § 30-20) Secs. 22-207—22-240. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PERSONAL CARE HOME FACILITIES
Sec. 22-241. - Policy. It shall be the policy of the city to provide for the establishment and regulation of personal care homes for the purpose of providing a safe, healthful and wholesome living environment for nonfamily ambulatory adults as an alternative to nursing homes and other similar institutional environments when such alternative living environments can be provided through the personal, protective care and watchful oversight of responsible supervisory adults. (Code 1976, § 22½-1) Sec. 22-242. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Ambulatory adult means a person 18 years of age or older who has the ability to move from place to place by walking, either unaided or aided by a prosthesis, brace, cane, crutches or hand rails, or by propelling a wheelchair, and can perceive an emergency condition, whether caused by fire or otherwise, and escape without human assistance using the normal means of egress. Commissioner means the commissioner of human resources. Department means the state department of human resources or its duly authorized representatives. Manager means the adult persons designated by the board of commissioners as responsible for the day-to-day management, administration and/or supervision of a personal care home. The manager shall be capable of operating the home in accordance with the rules and regulations set forth in this article. Kitchen facilities means a food preparation and serving facility which includes at least a stove, refrigerator, sink and sufficient cabinets, countertops and areas for storage, preparation and serving of meals and subsequent cleanup. Permit means authorization granted by the city to any person to operate a personal care home. Such a permit signifies satisfactory compliance with the rules and regulations set forth in this article. Personal care means protective care and watchful oversight of a resident who needs a watchful environment, but who does not have an illness, injury or disability which requires chronic or convalescent care, including medical and nursing services. For the purpose of this definition, the term "protective care and watchful oversight" includes, but is not limited to, a daily awareness by the management of the resident's functioning, his whereabouts, the making and reminding a resident of appointments for medical checkups, the ability and readiness to intervene if a crisis arises for a resident, supervision in areas of nutrition, medication and actual provision of transient medical care, with a 24-hour responsibility for the well-being of the resident. Personal care home and home mean a building, or group of buildings, facility or place in which is provided two or more beds and other facilities and services are provided, including rooms, meals and personal care for nonfamily ambulatory adults. For the purpose of this article, personal care homes shall be classified as family personal care homes, group personal care homes or congregate personal care homes. Such term does not include buildings which are devoted to independent living units which include kitchen facilities in which residents have the option of preparing and serving some or all of their own meals or boarding facilities which do not provide personal care. (1) Congregate personal care home means a home for adults which offers care to ten or more persons. (2) Family personal care home means a home for adults in a family-type residence, noninstitutional in character, which offers care to not more than three persons. (3) Group personal care home means a home for adult persons in a residence or other type of building, noninstitutional in character, which offers care to three—ten persons. Responsible person means the manager or other adult person who is responsible for specified duties in a personal care home. Sponsor means the sponsor of a resident or applicant for residence in a personal care home. Such person may be a relative, guardian or employee of an official agency responsible for the person's well-being. (Code 1976, § 22½-2) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-243. - Authorization. Personal care homes, as defined and discussed in this article exclusively, may be established and operated in the city, provided that the establishment and operation of personal care homes is performed in strict compliance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1976, § 22½-3) Sec. 22-244. - License required. No person shall, in any manner, establish and/or operate a personal care home within the city without first obtaining a license from the city. Upon satisfactory review of a license application, the city shall issue a license, which shall remain in effect for a period not to exceed 12 months. Any person operating a personal care home as authorized under a state permit issued prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be required to acquire a city license within 30 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived and to make whatever modifications are required for the operation of the personal care home to comply with all provisions of this article within six months after the issuance of such license. (Code 1976, § 22½-4) Sec. 22-245. - License fee. The fee for a license required by this article shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 22½-5) Sec. 22-246. - Requirements for acceptance of permit application. The city shall not accept a personal care home license application until such time as the applicant shall provide to the city a copy of a permit issued by the appropriate state agency authorizing the applicant to operate a personal care facility. The license issued by the city shall apply only to the same location, owner, management and conditions set out in the state permit. (Code 1976, § 22½-6) Sec. 22-247. - Compliance with state law. A person licensed by the city to operate a personal care home shall comply at all times with all local, state and federal laws and regulations applicable to the operation of such facility. (Code 1976, § 22½-7) Sec. 22-248. - Revocation of license. Upon a majority rule of the board of commissioners, the city may at any time revoke the license of a person to operate a personal care home after considering the evidence and testimony provided at a duly called public hearing, and determining that the continuation of the personal care home would not be in the best interest of the public due to the failure of management to strictly comply with the provisions of this article. (Code 1976, § 22½-8) Sec. 22-249. - Public hearing mandatory. Within 15 days of the receipt of a bona fide complaint presented by any person to the city regarding a personal care home, it shall be mandatory for the board of commissioners to schedule a public hearing for the purpose of determining the facts and appropriate actions relative to the operation and licensure of the personal care home in question. (Code 1976, § 22½-9) Sec. 22-250. - Zoning. Personal care homes of the types specifically provided for in this section shall be limited exclusively to the following zones within the city: (1) Family personal care homes: R-3, P-R and R-4. (2) Group personal care homes: R-4 and P-R. (3) Congregate personal care homes: C-3. (Code 1976, § 22½-10) Secs. 22-251—22-280. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - LIQUIDATION SALES
Sec. 22-281. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Fire and other altered goods sale means a sale held in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. Going out of business sale means a sale held in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that, upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be discontinued, including, but not limited to, the following sales: (1) Adjuster's; (2) Adjustment; (3) Alteration; (4) Assignee's; (5) Bankrupt; (6) Benefit of administrator's; (7) Benefit of creditor's; (8) Benefit of trustee's; (9) Building coming down; (10) Closing; (11) Creditor's committee; (12) Creditor's end; (13) Executor's; (14) Final days; (15) Forced out; (16) Forced out of business; (17) Insolvent's; (18) Last days; (19) Lease expires; (20) Liquidation; (21) Loss of lease; (22) Mortgage sale; (23) Receiver's; (24) Trustee's; (25) Quitting business. Goods means and includes any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this article. Removal of business sale means a sale held in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. (Code 1976, § 28-16) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-282. - Reserved. Sec. 22-283. - Exemptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following: (1) Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; (2) Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; (3) Duly licensed auctioneers selling at auction; (4) Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication who publishes in good faith any advertisement without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions of this article have not been complied with. (Code 1976, § 28-18) Sec. 22-284. - Established business requisite. Any person who has not been the owner of a business advertised or described in the application for a permit under this article for a period of at least six months prior to the date of the proposed sale shall not be granted a permit; provided, however, that the following shall be exceptions to this section: (1) Upon the death of a person doing business in the city, his heirs, devisees or legatees shall have the right to apply for a permit under this article at any time. (2) Damage by fire. (Code 1976, § 28-19) Sec. 22-285. - Interval between sales. Any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this article, at the location stated in the permit application, within one year from the date of such application, shall not be granted a permit. (Code 1976, § 28-20) Sec. 22-286. - Restricted location. Where a person applying for a permit under this article operates more than one place of business, the permit issued shall apply only to the one store or branch specified in the application, and no other store or branch shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with the permitted store or branch, or is in any way participating in the permitted sale, nor shall the store or branch conducting the permitted sale advertise or represent that any other store or branch is cooperating with it or participating in any way in the permitted sale. (Code 1976, § 28-21) Sec. 22-287. - Application for permit. A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this article shall make a written application to the board of commissioners, which shall set forth and contain the following information: (1) The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale; (2) A description of the place where such sale is to be held; (3) The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease, and the effective date of the termination of such occupancy; (4) The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted; (5) A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods by such sale, and the manner in which the sale will be conducted. (Code 1976, § 28-22) Sec. 22-288. - Fee. Any applicant for a permit under this article shall submit to the board of commissioners with his application a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 28-23) Sec. 22-289. - Period. The permit issued under this article shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of not more than 30 consecutive days following the issuance of such permit, excluding Sundays and legal holidays. (Code 1976, § 28-24) Sec. 22-290. - Surrender of general license. Upon being issued a permit for a going out of business sale, the permittee shall surrender to the board of commissioners all other business licenses he may hold at that time applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a permit under this article. (Code 1976, § 28-25) Sec. 22-291. - Assignability and transferability. Any permit issued under the provisions of this article shall not be assignable or transferable. (Code 1976, § 28-26) Sec. 22-292. - Advertising. A permittee under the provisions of this article shall: (1) Advertise properly. Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. (2) Adhere to advertising. Conduct the permitted sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incidental thereto. (Code 1976, § 28-27) Secs. 22-293—22-320. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - AUCTIONS[5] Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Auctioneers, O.C.G.A. § 43-6-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-321. - Compliance. No personal property, goods, wares or merchandise shall be sold at auction in the city, except in compliance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1976, § 28-39) Sec. 22-322. - Exception. The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to auction sales conducted by trustees or referees in bankruptcies, executors, administrators, receivers or other public officers acting under judicial process or the sale of real property at auction. (Code 1976, § 28-40) Sec. 22-323. - Location restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction sale of personal property, goods, wares, or merchandise on any of the streets, sidewalks or public property of the city. (Code 1976, § 28-41) Sec. 22-324. - Night auctions of jewelry and certain other articles. It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, auction or sell at auction any gold, silver, plated ware, clock, watch, diamond or other precious or semiprecious stone, or any imitation thereof, glassware, chinaware or jewelry, or any article purporting to be represented as any of such articles, between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. or at any time after sunset and before sunrise. (Code 1976, § 28-42) Secs. 22-325—22-350. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 22-351. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or cause or permit to be sold, at auction any personal property, goods, wares or merchandise within the city, unless such sale is conducted by an individual who has applied for and obtained an auctioneer's license from the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 28-49) Sec. 22-352. - Application. The form on which application for a license required by this division shall be made shall require the following information: (1) Name of the applicant. (2) Residence and business address of the applicant. (3) Length of time for which an auctioneer's license is desired. (4) A statement as to whether or not the applicant holds, or has held, an auctioneer's license from any state, municipality, governing body or licensing authority; a list of such licenses and a statement of the time, place and by whom such licenses were issued; a statement as to whether any state, municipality, governing body or licensing authority has ever refused to issue or renew an auctioneer's license to the applicant, together with a full and accurate statement as to the reasons for any such revocation. (5) A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of any crime, offense or violation of any municipal ordinance, and if so, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. (6) The names of two reliable property owners within the county who will certify as to the applicant's good moral character and business responsibility as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such moral character and business responsibility, except that the city clerk may waive such requirement with respect to an applicant for renewal of an auctioneer's license by an individual holding an unexpired auctioneer's license issued under this division who has in a previous application made under this division complied with such requirement. (Code 1976, § 28-50) Sec. 22-353. - Investigation. Before issuing an auctioneer's license to any individual applying therefor, the city clerk shall refer the application to the chief of police who shall cause an investigation of the applicant's moral character and business responsibility to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good, except that the city clerk may waive such requirement with respect to an application for renewal of an auctioneer's license by any individual holding an unexpired auctioneer's license issued under this division if an investigation of such applicant's moral character and business responsibility has previously been made under this section in connection with a prior application for an auctioneer's license under this division. The chief of police shall cause the investigation provided for in this section to be made within a reasonable time, and shall certify to the city clerk whether or not the moral character and business responsibility of the applicant is satisfactory. (Code 1976, § 28-51) Sec. 22-354. - Fees. The fees for an auctioneer's license shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 28-52) Sec. 22-355. - Issuance and renewal. The city clerk is hereby authorized to grant or renew an auctioneer's license for any period of time, not exceeding one year, to any individual applying therefor, on a form to be provided by the city clerk, upon payment by the applicant of the fees provided for in this division. (Code 1976, § 28-53) Sec. 22-356. - Reason for denial or revocation. An auctioneer's license may be revoked by the city clerk or any application, issuance or renewal of such license may be refused by the city clerk if he determines, after notice and hearing, that the: (1) Applicant or license holder is not an individual of good moral character and business responsibility; (2) Applicant's or license holder's application contains any false, fraudulent or misleading material; (3) Applicant or license holder has perpetrated a fraud upon any person, whether or not such fraud was perpetrated in the conduct of an auction within the city; (4) Applicant or license holder has made any false, fraudulent or misleading material statement in the course of conducting an auction sale, or offering for sale at auction, of any real or personal property, goods, wares or merchandise within the city; (5) Applicant or license holder has violated any of the statutes of the state relating to auctions or auctioneers; (6) Applicant has been convicted of any crime or offense involving moral turpitude; or (7) Applicant or license holder has conducted an auction sale or offered property, goods, wares or merchandise within the city in an unlawful manner, or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. (Code 1976, § 28-54) Sec. 22-357. - Notice of hearing. Notice of the hearing provided for in section 22-356 shall be given in writing to the applicant or license holder, as applicable. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to such applicant or license holder, at his last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. The applicant or license holder shall have the right to be represented at such hearing by counsel. (Code 1976, § 28-55) Sec. 22-358. - Appeal. Any individual aggrieved by the action of the city clerk in refusing to issue any license, or in revoking any license or special permit already issued, shall have the right to appeal to the board of commissioners. Such appeal shall be taken by filing a written statement, fully setting forth the grounds of the appeal, with the board of commissioners, or a person designated by the board, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed, postage prepaid, to such individual's last known address. The board of commissioners shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided in section 22-357. The applicant shall have the right to be represented at such hearing by counsel. The decisions and order of the board of commissioners on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. (Code 1976, § 28-56) Secs. 22-359—22-370. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - PAIN MANAGEMENT CLINICS[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- Editor's note— Ordinance of Feb. 7, 2012, §§ 1—14, enacted provisions which did not specify manner of inclusion. Hence, to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been included herein as Ch. 22, Art. VIII, §§ 22-371—33-384.
Sec. 22-371. - Definitions. Dispense means to issue one or more doses of any drug in a suitable container with appropriate labeling for subsequent administration to, or use by, a patient. This excludes hospitals, surgery centers, inpatient care facilities, assisted living facilities, outpatient facilities operated or owned by a hospital system or pharmacy, and pharmacies. Pain management clinic means any business entity, medical practice or physician which dispenses schedule II, III or IV drugs. Excluded from this definition is any practice of pharmacy which derives less than 25 percent of its gross revenues from the sale of schedule II, III or IV drugs in any calendar year. Provided that no pain management clinic or physician shall attempt to avoid this article by declaring itself a pharmacy. Pharmacy means any commercial enterprise which derives 50 percent or less of its gross revenues from the sale of schedule II, III or IV drugs. Physician means a person licensed to practice medicine under O.C.G.A. § 43-34-21. Practice of pharmacy means the interpretation, evaluation, or dispensing of prescription drug orders in the patient's best interest; participation in drug and device selection, drug administration, drug regimen reviews, and drug or drug related research; provision of patient counseling and the provision of those acts or services necessary to provide pharmacy care; performing capillary blood tests and interpreting the results as a means to screen for or monitor disease risk factors and facilitate patient education, and a pharmacist performing such functions shall report the results obtained from such blood tests to the patient's physician of choice; and the responsibility for compounding and labeling of drugs and devices, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 26-4-4. Responsible person shall mean any person licensed or authorized by the state or any board thereof to dispense drugs. Schedule II, III or IV drugs shall mean the drugs defined in O.C.G.A. §§ 16-13-26 through 16-13-29. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 1) Sec. 22-372. - Regulations. No person, firm, partnership, corporation or entity of any type shall dispense, sell, or make available schedule II, III or IV drugs, as defined above, without a valid pain management clinic and pain medication occupation tax certificate issued by the city pursuant to this article. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 2) Sec. 22-373. - Occupation tax certificate required. It is unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity of any type to dispense, sell, prescribe or make available schedule II, III or IV drugs, as defined above, without a valid pain management clinic and pain medication occupation tax certificate issued by the city pursuant to this article. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 3) Sec. 22-374. - Application contents. Each application for a pain management clinic and pain medication establishment occupation tax certificate, whether new or a renewal, shall contain the following information: (a) The applicant's full name. (b) The present address and telephone number of the applicant. (c) The business license of occupation tax history of the applicant and whether such applicant, in previous operations in this or any other city, state or territory under license, has or had such license or occupation tax certificate or similar type of business revoked or suspended, the reason therefore, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. (d) The overall business and occupational history of the applicant and whether such applicant, in previous operations in this or any other city, state or territory under license, has or had a business establishment closed, terminated operations or otherwise ceased operations due to the suspension or revocation of a business license or occupation tax certificate or due to the abandonment of such business establishment by the applicant. (e) If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the name, residence address of the partners. If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certificate of limited partnership filed with the county clerk. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply. The applicant corporation or partnership shall designate one of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated persons shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this charter, but only one application fee shall be charged. (f) If the applicant, any partners or any corporate officers, if the applicant is a corporation, has been convicted of a felony in the past five years and, if so, the applicant shall provide a complete description of any such crime including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether terms of disposition have been fully completed. (g) If the applicant is a person doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name properly recorded. If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of authority to do business in Georgia, including articles of incorporation, trade name affidavit, if any, last annual report, if any. (h) Address of the premises to be licensed. (i) Whether the premises are owned or rented. (j) Each applicant for a pain management clinic occupation tax certificate shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: (1) If the applicant is an individual, the individual; (2) If by a partnership, by the manager or general partnership; (3) If a corporation, by the president of the corporation or other registered officer; (4) If any other organization of association, by the chief administrative official. (k) Attach a copy of the applicant's current license or licenses issued by the state or any agency or board thereof. (l) If the applicant possessed or possesses such a license or licenses, then the applicant shall further provide the following: (1) The name and DEA number of every person authorized or licensed by the State of Georgia or any board thereof to dispense drugs, associated, or with an ownership interest in the business. (2) The business's website address. (3) Location of any other clinics or practices associated with or owned by the same parties as applicant. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 4) Sec. 22-375. - Application review. The city shall have up to 45 days to review the application and the background of the applicant. Upon completion of the review, the city manager may grant the license if he or she finds that: (a) The required fee has been paid. (b) Application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this chapter. (c) The applicant has not knowingly made a material misrepresentation in the application. (d) The applicant has fully cooperated in the review of his application. (e) The applicant, if an individual, or any officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not been convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of a felony. (f) On the date the business for which an occupation tax certificate is required herein commences, and thereafter, there will be a person authorized or licensed by the state or any board thereof to dispense drugs on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 5) Sec. 22-376. - Persons prohibited as applicants. No occupation tax certificate provided for by this chapter shall be issued to or held by: (a) An applicant who has not paid all required fees and taxes for a business at that location or property taxes. (b) Any applicant who does not have a valid and current license issued by the appropriate governmental or regulatory agency. (c) Any applicant who has been convicted of a felony in the last five years. (d) Any applicant who has had a business license or occupation tax certificate revoked or suspended for the alleged violation of penal or criminal laws governing the prescription or distribution of medication. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 6) Sec. 22-377. - Occupation tax certificate refusal, appeal. If the city, following review of the applicant, deems that the applicant does not fulfill the requirements as set forth in this chapter, it shall notify the city clerk of such opinion and, within 45 days of the date of application, provide copies of the review report to the city clerk. The city clerk shall, within ten days, notify applicant by certified mail of such denial. Any applicant who is denied an occupation tax certificate may appeal such denial to the mayor and city council by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days of the receipt of notice from the city clerk. A hearing before the mayor and city council shall be scheduled within 45 days of such notice. Whenever the city clerk has scheduled an appeal before the city council, at the time and date set therefore, the city council shall receive all relevant testimony and evidence from the applicant, from interested parties and from city staff. The city council may sustain, over-rule or modify the action complained of. The action of the city council shall be final. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 7) Sec. 22-378. - Renewal of occupation tax certificate. Occupation tax certificates for pain management clinics may be renewed on a calendar year basis provided that the applicants continue to meet the requirements set forth in this chapter. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 8) Sec. 22-379. - Occupation tax certificates nontransferable. No pain management clinic occupation tax certificate may be sold, transferred or assigned by a permittee, or by operation of law, to any other person or persons. Any such sale, transfer or assignment, shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such permit and such permit shall thereafter be null and void; provided and excepting, however, that if the applicant is a partnership and one or more of the partners should die, one or more of the surviving partners may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner or partners without effecting a surrender or termination of such occupation tax certificate upon notification to the city, shall be placed in the name of the surviving partner. A pain management clinic tax certificate issued to a corporation shall be deemed terminated and void when either any outstanding stock of the corporation is sold, transferred or assigned after the issuance of a permit, or any stock authorized but not issued at the time of the granting of an occupation tax certificate is thereafter issued and sold, transferred or assigned. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 9) Sec. 22-380. - Change of location or name. (a) No pain management clinic shall move from the location specified on its occupation tax certificate until a change of location fee, established by resolution of the city council, has been deposited with the city, and approval has been obtained from the city manager for the city. Such approval shall not be given unless all requirements and regulations, as contained in the city's codes, have been met. (b) No applicant shall operate, conduct, manage, engage in, or carry on a pain management clinic under any name other than his name and the name of the business as specified on his occupation tax certificate. (c) Any application for an extension of expansion of a building or other place of business where a pain management clinic is located shall require inspection and shall comply with the provisions and regulations of this chapter. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 10) Sec. 22-381. - Unlawful operation declared nuisance. Any pain management clinic operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this chapter shall be and the same is declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings for abatement, removal or enjoinment thereof, in the manner provided by law. It may take such other steps and shall apply to such court or courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such pain management clinic and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining a pain management clinic contrary to the provisions of this chapter. In addition, violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be per se grounds for suspension or revocation of the occupation tax certificate granted hereunder. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 11) Sec. 22-382. - Revocation and appeal. (a) The city manager shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an occupation tax certificate previously granted herein for a violation of this article. In the event the city manager seeks to suspend or to revoke an occupation tax certificate, the city manager shall give written notification to the applicant of such action and such notice shall contain a specification of the violation or violations and shall be served upon the licensee at least five days prior to the notice of hearing. The applicant shall be given written notice of the time and place of the hearing. (b) The city manager shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an occupation tax certificate in the event of any one or more of the following: (1) An applicant gave false or misleading information in the original application process; (2) An applicant has knowingly allowed the violation of an ordinance of the city or a violation of any criminal law of the state to occur on the premises; (3) An applicant has violated any provision of this pain management clinic chapter; (4) An applicant has been convicted of a felony; (5) An applicant fails to pay after its due date any fee, occupation tax, fine or other amount of money due to the city under this chapter or any other taxing ordinance of the city; and (6) The applicant's state license has been revoked or not renewed. (c) In the event the city manager shall suspend or revoke any occupation tax certificate hereunder, the suspension or revocation shall be for a period of not less than one day nor more than 365 days, within the discretion of the city manager. Provided, however, that the applicant shall be authorized to continue its business operations until that date of the hearing scheduled in accordance with subsection (d) of this section. No applicant may apply for an occupation tax certificate during any period of suspension or revocation. In any hearing conducted by the city manager, the city manager shall consider, among other things, the severity of the allegations, the evidence submitted and the testimony presented, in making any decision on suspension, revocation and the duration of either. (d) In the event of a suspension or revocation by the city manager, the applicant may appeal the decision of the city manager to the mayor and city council for the city by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days from the date of the decision of the city manager. Thereafter, a hearing shall be scheduled before the mayor and council for the city within 45 days after the date of the notice of appeal by the applicant. After hearing by the mayor and city council, city council may take such action as it deems appropriate, including the upholding of the action of the city manager or the imposition of such action as the mayor and city council may deem appropriate under the facts. The decision of the mayor and city council shall be final. Appeals from the decision of the mayor and city council shall be certiorari to the county superior court filed within 30 days to the final action of mayor and city council. In the event the applicant does not file an appeal from any decision of the city manager, as provided herein, the decision of the city manager shall be final. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 12) Sec. 22-383. - Exclusions. (a) No care service, palliative care service, hospice or palliative care home or facility, or other similar specialized medical home or treatment facility, home or entity shall be required to register hereunder unless otherwise required by another provision of this Code. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this provision shall not otherwise exempt or relieve any such person or persons from any other occupation tax certificate or business license requirement that might otherwise apply under the city code. (b) No physician who is actively and currently credentialed by any public hospital within the state or who actively maintains staff privileges at any public hospital within 70 miles of the city shall be required to register hereunder unless otherwise required by another provision. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this provision shall not otherwise exempt or relieve any such person or persons from any other occupation tax certificate or business license requirement that might otherwise apply under the city code. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 13) Sec. 22-384. - Limitations. Notwithstanding anything contained herein, this chapter shall not operate to impose a precondition or sanction on any applicant licensed by the state or any board or authority created by state law. (Ord. of 2-7-2012, § 14) Secs. 22-385—22-399. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - PAWNSHOP, PAWNBROKER, SECONDHAND DEALER, JUNK DEALER, JUNK COLLECTOR, COIN DEALER, GOLD BUYER, SILVER BUYER AND USED PRECIOUS METALS AND GEMS DEALER[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted June 19, 2018, repealed art. IX in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former art. IX, §§ 22-400—22-418, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from an ordinance adopted March 4, 2014, § 1.
Sec. 22-400. - Short title. This article shall be known as the "City of Jesup Pawnshop, Pawnbroker, Secondhand Dealer, Junk Dealer, Junk Collector, Coin Dealer, Gold Buyer, Silver Buyer and Used Precious Metals and Gems Dealer Ordinance." (Ord. of 6-19-2018(2)) Sec. 22-401. - Findings and intent. (a) This article is adopted to address and promote the interests of public safety, health and welfare of the City of Jesup and its citizens, to aid and assist in the recovery of stolen property, to aid and assist local law enforcement in fulfilling its public safety functions, and to facilitate peaceful, lawful, orderly and efficient pawn brokering, the purchase, sale and consignment of secondhand goods, the purchase and sale of junk or swap items, and the purchase and sale from members of the public of coins, gold, silver, and other used precious metals and gems within the City of Jesup. (b) The city recognizes that pawnshops, secondhand dealers, junk dealers, junk collectors, coin dealers, gold buyers, silver buyers, and used precious metals and gems dealers are legitimate businesses authorized by or otherwise permitted under state law. However, the city finds that the services offered by such forms of business may provide an opportunity for individuals to potentially transfer stolen property to those businesses. The city also finds that consumer protection regulation is warranted in transactions involving these businesses. The city further finds that the various purchase, sale, swap, consignment or pawn transactions of pawnshops, secondhand dealers and junk, coin, gold, silver and used precious metals and gems dealers have expanded beyond the city's current ability to effectively or efficiently identify criminal activity related to them. The purpose of the city's regulation of pawnshops, secondhand dealers, junk dealers, junk collectors, coin dealers, gold buyers, silver buyers, and used precious metals and gems dealers is to prevent such forms of business from being used to facilitate the commission of crimes and also to ensure that they comply with basic consumer protection standards, thereby protecting the public health, safety and general welfare of citizens, pursuant to authority granted to the city by state law and the Constitution of the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 6-19-2018(2)) Sec. 22-402. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, or in the alternative if so defined therein shall have the same meaning as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130, as amended from time to time, should those definitions differ.: Chief of police means the designated chief of police of the City of Jesup. City council means the governing body of the City of Jesup, Georgia. principally, the city commissioners and the mayor. Coin dealer means any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of buying or selling used or secondhand coins to and from the public for their value as collectors' items, for their value for gold, silver, or other precious metals content, or buying coins containing any gold, silver, or precious metals at a price above the face value of the coin. Conditional continuation means the finding and imposition of city council upon any person licensed or permitted to operate or work as an employee at any pawnshop, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, gold buyer, silver buyer, and used precious metals and gems dealer, that such person may only continue to conduct business under certain defined conditions or restrictions, as determined by the said city council. Employee means any person who works in a pawnshop or a pawnbroker's, secondhand dealer's, junk dealer's, junk collector's, coin buyer's, gold buyer's, silver buyer's, or used precious metals and gems dealer's shop or establishment, whether on a part-time or full-time basis, regardless of whether remuneration is received or is not and whether classified as an employee or independent contractor for taxation purposes. Gold buyer means any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the business of buying used or secondhand gold or objects made of gold or of gold alloy from the public. Junk collector means any person not having a fixed place of business in the city who goes from house to house, or from place to place, gathering, collecting, buying, selling, or otherwise dealing in for the purpose of financial gain any old rags, sacks, bottles, cans, papers, implements, vehicles, household items, equipment, art work, furniture, tools, metal or other articles commonly known as junk or scrap or salvage property. Junk dealer means any person (not an auto wrecker) engaged in conducting, managing or carrying on the business of buying, selling or otherwise dealing in, either at wholesale or retail old rags, sacks, bottles, cans, papers, implements, vehicles, household items, equipment, art work, furniture, tools, metal or other articles known as junk or scrap or salvage property. Month means that period of time from one date in a calendar month to the corresponding date in the following calendar month, but, if there is no such corresponding date, then the last day of such following month. Pawnbroker means any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed or permitted dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this paragraph. Pawn transaction means any loan on the security of pledged goods or any purchase of pledged goods on the condition that the pledged goods may be redeemed or repurchased by the pledgor or seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time. Person means an individual or any partnership, corporation, limited liability company, joint venture, trust, association, or any other legal entity however organized. Pledged goods means tangible personal property, including, without limitation, all types of motor vehicles or any motor vehicle certificate of title, which such property is purchased by, deposited with, or otherwise actually delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker or a pawnshop in connection with a pawn transaction. However, for purposes of this article, a pawnbroker or a pawnshop that comes into possession of any motor vehicle certificate of title through a pawn transaction made in accordance with applicable law shall be conclusively deemed to be possession of the motor vehicle, and the pawnbroker or the pawnshop may retain physical possession of the motor vehicle certificate of title for the entire length of the pawn transaction but shall not be required in any way to retain physical possession of the motor vehicle at any time. "Pledged goods" shall not include choses in action, securities, or printed evidences of indebtedness. Revocation means a complete forfeiture of the license or permit of an operator or employee of a pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, gold buyer, silver buyer and used precious metals and gems dealer by operation of this article and action by the city council. Secondhand dealer means any person, whether as owner, agent or employee whose business includes purchasing, storing, selling, or exchanging, and receiving secondhand personal property of any kind, or description to and from the public. However, any person, whether as owner, agent or employee whose business is the purchase and resale of clothing, furniture, or the resale of goods that are donated to the business as a charitable donation shall not be deemed a secondhand dealer under this article. (1) A secondhand dealer also includes, but is not limited to, a person who is engaged in a temporary location in the City of Jesup, in the business of selling or purchasing articles under this section. Such persons shall obtain a license or permit in compliance with this article. For the purposes of this subsection, a temporary location shall include, but shall not be limited to, a hotel or motel meeting room or guest room. (2) A secondhand jewelry dealer is also included in the definition of a secondhand dealer hereunder and also includes a person who is engaged in the business of selling or purchasing used jewelry from random members of the public, including, but not limited to, from a temporary location in the City of Jesup and such person shall also obtain a license or permit in compliance with this article. For the purposes of this subsection, a temporary location shall include, but shall not be limited to, a hotel or motel meeting room or guest room. Silver buyer means any person, firm, or corporation in the business of buying used or secondhand silver or objects made of silver or of silver alloy from the public. Suspension means a required temporary cessation of activity or business as an operator or employee of pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, gold buyer, silver buyer and used precious metals and gems dealer by operation of this article and action by the city council. A suspension may range from 14 days to 180 days based upon the severity of the offense for which the suspension is levied, as determined by the city council. Used precious metals and gems dealer means a person, firm, partnership, company or corporation that is engaged in the business of purchasing or selling of used or preowned articles made of or containing gold, silver, platinum. or other precious metals, gems or jewels of any description if, in any manner, including any form of advertisement or solicitation of customers, the person holds himself, herself, or itself out to the public as willing to purchase such articles from members of the public or to sell such articles to the public. Exemptions. Any transaction wherein a secondhand dealer purchases goods for resale to the public from or at a foreclosure sale involving the foreclosure of a storage house lien shall not be subject to the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 6-19-2018(2)) Sec. 22-403. - Enforcement. The municipal police department of the city shall see that the provisions of this article are observed and enforced. (Ord. of 6-19-2018(2)) Sec. 22-404. - Employees. No person shall be an employee, part time or full time, or independent contractor of a pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer in any capacity until such person has been fingerprinted by the municipal police department and has been issued an annual permit or license authorizing such person to be employed by or contracted to a pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer within the City of Jesup. It shall be the duty of the pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer to ensure that there is compliance with the provisions of this section. The City of Jesup will assess an initial administrative fee for all new permits or licenses of $55.00, or such other amounts as the city council may determine from time to time through resolution. (Ord. of 6-19-2018(2)) Sec. 22-405. - General policies and procedures. (a) Any pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer within the city may operate only after the issuance of a license or permit for such operation by the city and only in the manner permitted by such license or permit, this article and the laws of the State of Georgia. Pawn transactions and purchase and sale transactions by pawnshops, pawnbrokers, secondhand dealers, junk dealers, junk collectors, coin dealers, coin buyers, silver buyers or used precious metals and gems dealers may only occur through a licensee or permittee who complies with the rules and regulations of this article and with the licensing, regulatory and revenue reporting requirements of the State of Georgia and the United States Government. (b) The license or permit issued to a pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer under this article shall be in addition to any other license or permit required by, or license or permitting fees or other charges imposed or collected by, the city and shall not otherwise excuse or eliminate the requirement or obligation of such licensee or permittee under this article from obtaining, procuring, carrying or displaying any other licenses or permits required by the city or paying such other fees or charges. (c) All licenses or permits are a mere grant or privilege subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this article and state law and are subject to being revoked by the city. (d) Each licensee or permittee of the city shall display the license or permit issued under this article prominently at all times at the outlet, location or physical site for which the license or permit is issued. A separate license or permit must be issued for each such outlet, location or site within the city, and a separate application must be made for each such outlet, location or site. (e) It is the general policy of this article to impede the transference of stolen goods through the use and abuse of any pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer to effectuate the transfer of stolen goods. This article shall further function to ensure that any pawnshop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer does not become a medium for the transference or movement of stolen goods. (Ord. of 6-19-2018(2)) Sec. 22-406. - Qualification for issuance of license or permit. (a) Any person who desires to obtain a license or permit for the operation of a pawnshop or to otherwise carry on the business of a pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer must meet the minimum qualifications set forth in this section. If the applicant is a partnership, each partner must meet the qualifications of any individual license or permit and must make sworn statements of these qualifications as part of the applications process. If the applicant is a corporation, the majority stockholder and each principal officer of the corporation must meet the qualifications as part of the applications process. If the applicant is a limited liability company, each member must meet the qualifications of any individual license or permit. The minimum qualifications include the following: (1) No owner, employee, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, junk collector, coin dealer, coin buyer, silver buyer or used precious metals and gems dealer for which a license or permit is sought shall have been convicted of a crime involving "moral turpitude" or shall have been convicted of any crime involving felony theft, burglary, robbery, or a violation of the "Family Violence Act." (2) No license or permit shall be granted to an applicant who is under the age of 18 years of age. (3) All persons filing an application for a license or permit under this article will be required to complete a waiver in order for the applicant's criminal history to be obtained.
