No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or other person then present in or upon such private premises; provided, however, that in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted, such person, unless requested by any person upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises if such handbill is placed or deposited so as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or sidewalks, streets or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not be used for such distribution when prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. (Code 1976, § 18-45) Secs. 82-157—82-180. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 82-181. - Compliance. It shall be unlawful for any person to stand upon or in close proximity to a street, highway or other public thoroughfare in the city for the purpose of handing out handbills or other such matter to occupants of automobiles or other vehicles traveling upon such street, highway or other public thoroughfare without first complying with the requirements of this article. (Code 1976, § 18-53) Sec. 82-182. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver, hand out, distribute or otherwise circulate, or to cause to be delivered, handed out, distributed or otherwise circulated, except by United States Postal Service, any handbill, circular, poster, pamphlet or similar written matter upon any municipal street, sidewalk or public place within the city without obtaining a permit. (Code 1976, § 18-54) Sec. 82-183. - Application. Each person desiring to obtain a permit required by the provisions of this division shall make written application for such permit to the board of commissioners, which application shall contain the following information: (1) Name, age, race and address of the applicant. (2) Name, address and type business of the person for whom such handbills or other matter will be distributed. (3) Locations from which the applicant desires to engage in such activity, which shall be described in detail. (4) Experience of the applicant in the activity of handing out such literature. (5) Hours during which the applicant intends to distribute such literature. (6) Such other information as may be required by the board of commissioners to enable them to pass upon such application. (Code 1976, § 18-55) Sec. 82-184. - Fee. A fee is assessed as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for a permit required by this division, which amount shall accompany each application, and no application shall be received until and unless a cashier's or certified check in such amount accompanies each such application. No portion of such fee shall be prorated or rebated to any permittee who ceases to engage in any such activity. (Code 1976, § 18-56) Sec. 82-185. - Standards. The following standards shall be adhered to in the granting of any permit under the provisions of this division: (1) No permittee shall be less than 21 years of age. (2) No more than one permit shall be issued for any street corner. (3) Traffic conditions at street or highway intersections will be considered in passing upon any application. (4) Each permit shall be issued only to an individual and may not be transferred or assigned without the consent of the board of commissioners, and no other person shall engage in such activity, except the person named in the permit. (Code 1976, § 18-57) Sec. 82-186. - Revocation. Any permit issued pursuant to this division may be revoked for cause and after hearing for any conduct of a permittee amounting to a nuisance, or calculated to impede the orderly flow of traffic. (Code 1976, § 18-58) Sec. 82-187. - Duration of validity. Every permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be valid for a period of time as stated in the permit, but in no event shall any such permit be issued for a period of time in excess of 12 months. (Code 1976, § 18-59) Sec. 82-188. - Display. Every person having a permit issued under the provisions of this division shall display such permit upon the request of any person, and failure to do so shall be deemed an offense. (Code 1976, § 18-60)

div.head: Chapter 86 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(9); any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(15); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; peddlers, § 22-101 et seq.; solicitors, § 22-181 et seq.; cable communications, ch. 26; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; manufactured homes, ch. 62; parades, § 66-41 et seq.; planning and zoning, ch. 70; railroads, ch. 74; throwing or depositing litter in public places, § 82-82; sweeping or depositing into gutters, streets or public places responsibility for keeping sidewalks free of litter § 82-84; throwing or distributing handbills in public places, § 82-152; traffic, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 98; vegetation, ch. 102; vehicles for hire, ch. 106; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B; street design requirements, app. B, art. XI. State Law reference— State, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; authority to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alley means a minor way to be used primarily for vehicular access to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. No alley, whether called an alley, lane or other designation, shall measure less or more than 20 feet in width. Street means a way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place or however otherwise designated. (1) Arterial street means a fast or heavy traffic street of considerable continuity, and used primarily as a traffic street artery for intercommunication among other areas, and shall not measure less than 80 feet in width. (2) Collector street means a street which carries traffic from minor streets to arterial streets, including the principal entrance streets of a residential development and streets for circulation within such a development, and shall not measure less than 60 feet in width. (3) Marginal access street means a minor street which is parallel and adjacent to arterial streets, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic, and shall not measure less than 50 feet in width. (4) Minor street means a street used primarily for access to the abutting properties, and shall not measure less than 50 feet in width. (Code 1976, § 31-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 86-2. - Approval of dedication. No dedication to the city by any owner of property to be used as a street or alley shall be valid until such property shall have been accepted in writing by the city engineer or other duly designated official. It shall be the duty of the city engineer to examine all applications for dedications of streets and alleys, and determine if they meet the requirements of this section and the other ordinances and rules adopted by the board of commissioners. The city engineer shall determine whether a right-of-way shall be designated as an alley, arterial, collector, minor or marginal access street. (Code 1976, § 31-2) Sec. 86-3. - Dumping on city property. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed, in any street or alley, any dirt, trash or any other material so as to interfere with the drainage or use of such street or alley, without first obtaining a permit to do so from the city engineer. (Code 1976, § 31-3) Sec. 86-4. - Removing soil from street. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove soil from any street, or make any excavation in any street or alley without first obtaining a permit to do so from the city engineer. (Code 1976, § 31-4) Sec. 86-5. - Restrictions on wheels; exceptions. (a) No vehicle load, any portion of which drags or slides on the surface of the roadway, shall be used or transported on the streets. (b) No vehicle shall be used or transported on the streets either from construction or otherwise, the wheels of which cause pounding on the road surface. (c) No vehicle equipped with solid tires shall be used or transported on the streets, unless every tire on such vehicle shall have rubber on its entire traction surface of at least one inch thickness above the edge of the flange of the entire periphery. (d) No vehicle shall be used or transported on the streets, the wheels of which have any wooden or metal cleats, spikes, corrugations or other irregularities on the surface which tend to damage the surface of the street. (e) Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to unimproved streets. (Code 1976, § 31-5) Sec. 86-6. - Interfering with cleaning crews. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle of any nature on the paved streets of the city between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on each Sunday morning, or to park any automobile on any street at any time in such a manner as to obstruct the cleaning crews. Any automobile found parked in violation of this provision shall be impounded by the police department and shall be moved or towed away. Such automobile shall be returned to the owner upon payment of any and all towing and storing charges incurred by the city, together with any penalty or fine that may be imposed for such violation. (Code 1976, § 31-6) Sec. 86-7. - Street specifications. The specifications and standards for the construction and repair of the public streets of the city shall be as adopted by the board of commissioners from time to time. (Code 1976, § 31-7) Sec. 86-8. - E 911 director to approve new street names. The names of all new streets, roads and rights-of-way shall be approved by the E 911 director before such names are voted upon and approved by the board of commissioners, provided, the decision of the E 911 director shall be based solely on whether the name of a new street, road or right-of-way is the same or so similar to an existing name as to cause confusion to E 911 personnel. The E 911 director shall provide the board of commissioners in writing with his specific reasons for the disapproval of the name of any new street, road or right-of-way. (Code 1976, § 31-8) Sec. 86-9. - Numbering of buildings. (a) Required. All houses, buildings, structures and lots within the city shall be numbered in accordance with a plan designated by the city. (b) Records. The fire chief shall keep records showing the proper street number of every lot within the city, which record shall be open for inspection by any interested person. (c) Legibility. It shall be the duty of the owners and occupants of every house, building and structure within the city to have placed thereon, in a place visible from the street, figures at least 3½ inches high, and colored differently from the material on which such figures are mounted, showing the number of the house, building, structure or lot. (d) Violation; penalty. Any person failing to number any house, building, structure or lot owned or occupied by him, after receiving notice to do so from the clerk, shall be subject to a fine of $5.00 for each day during or on which a failure to number such house, building, structure or lot continues. (Code 1976, § 6-1) Sec. 86-10. - Permanent structures. No permanent structure shall be constructed within 75 feet of either side of the present right-of-way of that section Sunset Boulevard extending from US 301 South to GA 84 West, with the exception of asphalt or concrete paving. (Ord. of 7-17-2007) Secs. 86-11—86-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ENCROACHMENTS, OBSTRUCTIONS
Sec. 86-41. - Prohibited; nuisance declared. It shall be unlawful for any person to encroach by fence, or in any other way, upon any part of a street, lane, alley or other thoroughfare, and it shall be unlawful to maintain any building, steps or any other obstructions in any street, lane, alley or other thoroughfare, and every such encroachment is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (Code 1976, § 31-19) Sec. 86-42. - Removal. If, at any time, it shall appear that any person is encroaching upon or maintaining any obstruction in any part of a street, lane, alley or other thoroughfare, it shall be the duty of the city marshal or designee to give notice to such party, ordering the removal of such encroachment or obstruction; and if such encroachment or obstruction is not removed within 24 hours after receipt of such notice, or such other reasonable time as may be designated by the board of commissioners, it shall be the duty of the city marshal or designee to cause any such encroachment or obstruction to be summarily removed, and the cost and expense thereof shall be charged to the person maintaining the encroachment or obstruction. (Code 1976, § 31-20) Sec. 86-43. - Building materials in streets. No person shall put any lumber, wood, boxes, bricks or other such obstructions in any street, alley or sidewalk without the permission of the building inspector. (Code 1976, § 31-21) Sec. 86-44. - Warning signals required at obstructions. Any person who shall cause any obstruction to be placed in any street, alley or sidewalk of the city shall display a sufficient danger signal or light at such obstruction to warn the traveling public of such obstruction and to enable them to avoid injury from such obstruction. (Code 1976, § 31-22) Sec. 86-45. - Right of city to remove or trim trees, shrubs or growths. The city shall have the right to cut down, remove or trim any tree, shrub or growth, or portion thereof, standing on the streets or sidewalks of the city or upon the private property of any person within the city, whenever, by order of the mayor and board of commissioners, it shall be necessary to protect any person or the property of any individual in the city from injury or damage. It shall be the duty of the city to notify such owner, or the agent of the owner or the tenant in possession of such property, to remove such tree, shrub or growth within five days; and if, at the expiration of such time, such tree, shrub or growth is not removed, the person so offending shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. If at the expiration of the time expressed in such notice the tree, shrub or growth has not been removed, the city shall have the right to remove the tree, shrub or growth, and to issue execution against the owner of such property for the amount of expenses incurred by reason of such removal, and enforce the execution in the same manner as other executions of the city are enforced. (Code 1976, § 31-23) Sec. 86-46. - Traffic obstruction. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the streets or sidewalks of the city, except as permitted by the ordinances of the city. (b) All persons responsible for altering or having altered the conditions of city sidewalks, roads, and streets through such actions as utility cuts, excavations, access modifications, and other such actions which disrupt the smooth and uninterrupted flow of traffic shall obtain a permit from the city and provide immediate relief in the form of temporary, all weather improvements, approved by the city engineer, that shall restore the smooth and uninterrupted flow of traffic within 24 hours of having begun such disruptions. Permanent restoration of the sidewalk, street, or roadway shall be completed within seven days of the date of having begun such disruption. (c) Any building or construction permit associated with activities that require disturbance of city sidewalks, roads, and streets shall designate such activities within the permit. Building permits for activities not in compliance with these provisions of issuance and restoration shall be stayed until the permit and worksite are found to be in compliance with this section. No work may continue at a worksite where the building permit has been stayed except such work permitted by the city engineer or building inspector required to correct those conditions for which the permit was stayed. (d) The city manager may grant written relief from strict compliance with these requirements provided such relief be supported by a finding of the city engineer or building inspector stating that strict compliance is unreasonable or impractical. Such finding must also contain an alternate plan and schedule for restoration of smooth and uninterrupted traffic. (e) Each 24-hour period that sidewalk and street traffic remains interrupted as provided in this section shall constitute a separate offense. (f) The penalty for the violation of this section shall be as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. (Ord. of 12-2-2008) Secs. 86-47—86-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ABANDONMENT OF STREETS, ALLEYS
Sec. 86-81. - Petition required. Any person desiring that any street or alley, or portion thereof, be abandoned by the city, shall file a written petition to the board of commissioners requesting such abandonment and containing the following: (1) A legal description of the street or alley, or portion thereof, sought to be abandoned. (2) Name and address of the petitioner. (3) Names and addresses of the owners of all property abutting the property sought to be abandoned. (4) Written consent of all of the owners of the property abutting the property sought to be abandoned. (Code 1976, § 31-35) Sec. 86-82. - Application fee. Any person filing a petition for the abandonment of any street or alley, or portion thereof, shall pay to the city, at the time such petition is filed, an application fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 31-36) Sec. 86-83. - Notice of petition. Upon receipt of a petition filed under this article, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to cause an advertisement to be published in the official newspaper of the city once a week for three weeks immediately preceding the meeting at which such application shall be considered by the board of commissioners, and such advertisement shall be in substantially the following form: Notice is hereby given that a petition has been filed with the board of commissioners for the City of Jesup requesting the abandonment of the following street or alley, or portion thereof, described as follows: (description) A public hearing will be held on such application at the regular meeting of the board of commissioners for the City of Jesup, to be held on the _____ day of ________, 20___. All persons are cited to be and appear at such hearing to show cause why such application should not be granted. This _____ day of ________, 20___.
(Code 1976, § 31-37) Sec. 86-84. - Inspection; report. The city clerk shall refer a copy of the petition filed under this article to the city manager. It shall be the duty of the city manager to inspect the street or alley, or portion thereof, sought to be abandoned and to determine if the street or alley, or portion thereof, is open and in use, and if it is needed, or likely to be needed, by the city in the future for right-of-way or other purposes, and it shall also be the duty of the city manager to determine the value of such property. The city manager shall make a written report of his findings to the board of commissioners. (Code 1976, § 31-38) Sec. 86-85. - Hearing; vacation procedure. At a public hearing, the board of commissioners shall hear all parties favoring or opposing the granting of an application under this article for the abandonment of a street or alley, or portion thereof, and determine if such street or alley, or portion thereof, shall be abandoned. If the board of commissioners shall determine that such application shall be granted, they shall also determine the value of such property. After such determination, the applicant shall be notified of the determination of such amount and shall deposit the amount with the city clerk, whereupon the board of commissioners shall proceed, by ordinance, to abandon such property, and to authorize the execution and delivery of a quit claim deed to the owners of the adjoining property. (Code 1976, § 31-39)

div.head: Chapter 90 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or evidence of the city's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(2); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(9); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-6(a)(14); administration, ch. 2; alcoholic beverage tax, § 6-91 et seq.; malt beverage excise tax, § 6-121 et seq.; businesses and business regulations, ch. 22; finances, ch. 42. State Law reference— Local government budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 90-1. - Property subject to taxation. All real and personal property situated within the city, whether owned by individuals, firms or corporations, resident or nonresident, regardless of whether such personal property is primarily used outside the city, unless exempt under the laws of the state, shall be subject to an ad valorem tax as may be lawfully levied on such personal property according to the constitution and laws of the state and the Charter and ordinances of the city, and according to the value of the personal property as of January 1 of each year. (Code 1976, § 32-1) Sec. 90-2. - Payment of taxes. All taxes shall be paid on or before December 31 of each year. (Code 1976, § 32-8) Sec. 90-3. - Tax executions to issue. Whenever any person shall fail or refuse to pay any ad valorem tax lawfully assessed by the city within the time required in this article, the city treasurer shall issue an execution for the amount due, plus costs, directed to the city marshal, to be disposed of by him as provided by law. (Code 1976, § 32-9) Sec. 90-4. - Duty of the city marshal. Whenever an execution is placed in his hands, the city marshal shall immediately give notice to the defendant in fi. fa., by due course of mail, not registered, advising such person to make payment of such fi. fa. within 15 days from the date of such notice, otherwise, a levy will be made. If such person shall fail or refuse to pay the amount due, the marshal shall levy such fi. fa. on the property of the defendant in fi. fa. and sell the property according to law in such case. All fi. fas. shall be returned by the marshal to the clerk within 90 days after receipt of the fi. fa., with his actions and doings entered thereon. If the marshal can find no property on which to levy such fi. fa., it shall be his duty to enter such fact on such fi. fa. The treasurer shall then issue a summons of garnishment, which shall be served by the marshal, directed to any person holding funds of the defendant, as provided by law. (Code 1976, § 32-10) Sec. 90-5. - Record of property purchased and sold. It shall be the duty of the clerk of the board of commissioners to prepare and keep a record of all property purchased and sold by the city at the marshal's tax sales, showing whose property was purchased, the amount bid for the property and what portion of the property was tax and costs. (Code 1976, § 32-11) Sec. 90-6. - How property sold by city. Property purchased by the city at the marshal's tax sales shall be sold and disposed of by the city as follows: The clerk shall annually present to the board of commissioners a full description of all properties so purchased during the year, together with a list of all other properties theretofore obtained by the city at such sales, undisposed of, and the board of commissioners shall determine if, in their opinion, it is to the best interest of the city to dispose of such property. If the board of commissioners should determine to sell such property, they shall, by resolution, direct the sale of the property by advertising the sale in the newspaper published in the city once a week for four weeks before the date of the sale, and on such date, between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., such property shall be sold to the highest bidder for cash before the city hall. Purchasers shall receive a quit claim deed to such property. No property purchased by the city at the marshal's tax sales shall be sold at private sale by the city. (Code 1976, § 32-12) Secs. 90-7—90-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAX[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22. State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
Sec. 90-41. - Required for business dealings with the city. For the year 1995 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation within the city, whether with a location in the city, or a location within the state with no location within the city, or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for such business, trade, profession or occupation, which tax and any applicable certificate shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location within the city; however, if the taxpayer has no permanent business location within the city, such business tax certificate shall be shown to the city marshal, city building inspector or his deputies, or to any police officer of the city, upon their request. (Code 1976, § 17-1) Sec. 90-42. - Purpose and scope. The occupation tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes only and not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. The occupation tax applies to the businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5—48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Code 1976, § 17-10) Sec. 90-43. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a component of an occupational tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. City of Jesup and city mean Jesup, Georgia. Commercial class of business means a business in the business categories that have a standard industrial classification (SIC) number in which the first two digits are digits other than those between 20 and 39. Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple line business from which the greatest amount of income is derived. Gross receipts means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including, but not limited to, the following: (1) Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; (2) Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets or instruments of indebtedness; (3) Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods or service; (4) Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and (5) Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty or dividend income. The term "gross receipts" shall not include the following: (1) Sales, use or excise tax; (2) Sales returns, allowances and discounts; (3) Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary-controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister-controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(2); (4) Payments made to a subcontractor or independent agent; and (5) Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this article, if such funds constitute 80 percent or more of the organization's receipts. Industrial class of business means a business in the business categories that have a standard industrial classification (SIC) number in which the first two digits are between 20 and 39. Location of office shall not include a temporary worksite which serves a single customer or project. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue raising purposes. Person includes a sole proprietor, corporation, partnership or any other form of business organization. Practitioners of professions and occupations means one who, by state law, requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Such term shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8), or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development, are not regulatory fees. (Code 1976, § 17-2) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 90-44. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure. (a) A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk shall be required on all business occupation tax accounts for the initial startup, renewal or reopening of such accounts. (b) A regulatory fee will only be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on such applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. (Code 1976, § 17-3) Sec. 90-45. - Levied; restrictions; schedule. (a) [Reserved.] (b) Schedule. (1) For the industrial class, the occupation tax shall be levied according to the number of employees of the business, which shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (2) For the commercial class, the occupation tax classification for each business, trade, profession or occupation shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1976, § 17-4; Ord. of 12-20-2005(2)) Sec. 90-45.5. - Business occupational rates. (a) Non-refundable administration fee ..... $ 50.00 (b) Tax Class 1 (.00070) ..... 0.60 Building construction, general contractors. Local and suburban transit and intersuburban highway passenger transportation. Motor freight transportation and warehousing. Transportation by air. Services incidental to transportation. Wholesale trade—Durable goods. Wholesale trade—Nondurable goods. Retail trade—Building materials, hardware, garden supply, and mobile home dealers. Retail trade—Food stores. (Ord. of 12-20-2005(3), § I) Sec. 90-46. - Payment by business with no location in the state. The city requires a registration and assessment of an occupation tax on businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business' largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: (1) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Owns personal or real property which generates income, and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. (Code 1976, § 17-5) Sec. 90-47. - Identification of each dominant line of business on business registration. The business registration of each business operated within the city shall identify the dominant line of business that the business conducts. (Code 1976, § 17-6) Sec. 90-48. - Each business location considered separate business. Where a person conducts business at more than one store or place, each store or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the occupation tax. (Code 1976, § 17-7) Sec. 90-49. - Practitioners of professions as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9. Practitioners of professions, as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18), shall elect, for the year 1995 and subsequent years, one of the following as their entire occupation tax: (1) The occupation tax based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios as set forth in section 90-44. (2) A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk, per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, which tax shall be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this subsection shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per practitioner fee shall include all persons in the business who qualify as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. (Code 1976, § 17-8) Sec. 90-50. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for the government. Any practitioner whose office is maintained, and who is employed in practice exclusively, by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for such practice. (Code 1976, § 17-9) Sec. 90-51. - When due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. (a) Each business tax shall be for the calendar year 1995 and succeeding calendar years thereafter, unless otherwise specifically provided. The registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year, and shall be delinquent if not paid by April 1 of each year, and shall be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in this article. On any new profession, trade or calling begun in the city in 1995 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and occupation tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business, and a ten percent penalty shall be imposed if such tax is not paid within 90 days of the commencement of the business. The tax certificate provided for in this article shall be issued by the city clerk, and if any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after such registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact, or offer to transact, any of the kinds of professions, trades or callings specified in this chapter within the city without having first obtained such registration, in addition to remedies provided in this article, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 90-79. (b) In addition to the remedies set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the city marshal or building inspector may proceed to collect such tax in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. (Code 1976, § 17-11) Sec. 90-52. - Allocation of employees or gross receipts of business with multiple intrastate or interstate locations. (a) For businesses who have multiple locations inside and outside of the city where the gross receipts can be allocated to each location, the gross receipts used to determine the occupational tax assessed will be the gross receipts attributed to each city location. In the case where the dollar amount of gross receipts attributed locally cannot be determined in businesses with multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in the city and elsewhere, and allotted to such locations. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide the following to the city: (1) Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and (2) Information relating to the allocation of the business' or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. (b) Where the business has locations outside of the city and taxation is levied for a criteria other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. (c) For the industrial class, only the employees who work in the city will be counted for taxing purposes. (Code 1976, § 17-12) Sec. 90-53. - Exemption for businesses operated for charitable purposes. No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from such registration or tax on the grounds that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 80 percent or more of the entire proceeds from such business are devoted to such purpose. (Code 1976, § 17-13) Sec. 90-54. - Evidence of state licensure required. Each person who is licensed under title 43 of the state license examining boards shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. (Code 1976, § 17-14) Sec. 90-55. - Evidence of qualification required. (a) Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence of such qualification. (b) Any business required to submit an annual application for continuance of such business shall do so before the registration is issued. (Code 1976, § 17-15) Sec. 90-56. - Registration required; liability of officers and agents; failure to obtain. All persons subject to the occupation tax provided in this article shall be required to take out the necessary registration for such business as prescribed in this article, and in default thereof, the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a certificate. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall also obtain the registration provided for in this article before commencing such business; and any person transacting, or offering to transact, within the city, any of the kinds of businesses, trades, professions or occupations without first having obtained such registration, shall be subject to penalties provided in this article and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 90-79. (Code 1976, § 17-16) Sec. 90-57. - When registration and tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax is delinquent. (a) Each registration shall be for the calendar year 1995 and each succeeding calendar year thereafter, unless otherwise specifically provided. There is hereby imposed a penalty upon each business which fails to apply for and obtain an appropriate business registration and pay all taxes and fees as provided in this article before April 1 of each year. The penalty for failure to comply with this section shall be assessed in the amount of ten percent of the administrative fee and occupational tax determined to be due and owing under the provisions of this article for the first 30 days, or fraction thereof, of delinquency, and an additional one percent of the administrative fee and occupation tax for each additional month, or fraction thereof, of delinquency. Such penalties shall be in addition to all other penalties, civil and criminal, provided in this article, and may be collected by the remedies provided in this article for collection of the occupation tax, and shall have the same lien and priority as the occupation tax to which the penalty is applied. (b) The registration certificate provided for in this article shall be issued by the city clerk, and if any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after such occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact, or offer to transact, within the city, any of the kinds of businesses, trades, professions or occupations without having first obtained such registration, shall be subject to the penalties provided in this article. (Ord. of 2-6-2001, § 17-17) Sec. 90-58. - Deputy marshal/business inspector. The city marshal or city building inspector and his duly designated officer and inspectors or successors shall be classified as deputy marshal/business inspector, with full subpoena and arresting powers, in conjunction with any violation pertaining to the business tax ordinance of 1995, as set forth in this article, and succeeding years thereafter. (Code 1976, § 17-18) Sec. 90-59. - Businesses not covered by this article. The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article, but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by act of local law: (1) Businesses regulated by the state public service commission. (2) Electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. tit. 46, ch. 3. (3) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. (4) Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. (5) Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. (6) Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. (7) Businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (8) Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. (9) Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (10) Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. (Code 1976, § 17-20) Sec. 90-60. - Where inapplicable. The occupation tax levied in this article is not levied upon the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of the state or the United States. (Code 1976, § 17-21) Sec. 90-61. - Levied on business to be transacted during calendar year; filing of returns showing gross receipts during preceding calendar year. (a) All occupation taxes levied by this article are levied on the amount of business to be transacted during the calendar year. However, for convenience of both the city and the taxpayer, and the necessity of making numerous returns, the businesses subject to the occupation tax levied in sections 90-45 and 90-49 shall, on or before the times set forth in this section, file with the city marshal the returns specifically provided for in this section, showing the gross receipts of the business during the preceding calendar year. The return shall be used as an estimate for making payments on the occupation tax for the current calendar year. The actual and final amount of tax levied for business transacted in a current calendar year shall be paid in accordance with a final return to be made after the termination of the year, in accordance with the procedure set forth in this section. (b) The owner, proprietor, manager or secretary officer of the business subject to such occupation tax for the current calendar year shall, at the end of the preceding year, and on or before April 1 of the current calendar year, file with the city marshal of the city, on a form furnished by the city marshal, a signed return, setting forth the amount of gross receipts of such business for the entire preceding calendar year to be used as an estimate of the gross receipts for the current year. The return calendar year 1995 shall include the gross receipts for calendar year 1994. (c) Where a business subject to the occupation tax for the calendar year has been conducted for only a part of the preceding year, the amount of gross receipts for such part of the year shall be set forth in such return. Such return shall also show a figure putting the receipts for such part of a year on an annual basis, which figure shall bear the same ratio to the amount of gross receipts for such part of the year as the full year bears to such part. Such figure shall be used as the estimate of the gross receipts of the business for the current calendar year. (Code 1976, § 17-22) Sec. 90-62. - When occupation tax due and payable; when delinquent. The amount of the occupation tax shall be payable to the city at the office of the finance department on January 1 each year, and shall be delinquent if not paid on or before April 1 each year. (Code 1976, § 17-23) Sec. 90-63. - Newly established businesses. In the case of a business subject to the occupation tax for a calendar year which was not conducted for any period of time within the corporate limits of the city in the preceding year, the owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of the business liable for such occupation tax shall estimate the gross volume of revenue from the commencing date to the end of the calendar year, and such tax shall be paid as provided in section 90-51. (Code 1976, § 17-24) Sec. 90-64. - More than one place or one line of business. Where a business is operated at more than one place or includes more than one line, the gross receipts of each location will be entered on a separate occupation tax return and the tax will be calculated at the rate of the dominant line of business conducted by the business identified on a form to be furnished by the city. (Code 1976, § 17-25) Sec. 90-65. - Filing of return showing actual gross receipts during calendar year; procedure where taxes overpaid or underpaid. (a) After the end of each year and on or before April 1 of the succeeding year, the owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of a business liable for such occupation tax levied for the year shall file with the city clerk, on a form furnished by the city clerk, a signed return setting forth the actual amount of the gross receipts of such business during the calendar year. (b) If the amount of the occupation tax due for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of such tax provided for in this article, exceeds the amount of occupation tax paid by such business based on the estimate filed pursuant to section 90-61, the difference in such amount shall be due and payable by the taxpayer to the city on April 1 of the current year, and shall be delinquent if not paid on or before such date. (c) If the amount of the occupation tax due for the preceding year, based on the return provided for in this section and on the rate of such tax provided for in this article, is less than the amount of occupation tax paid by such business based on the estimate filed pursuant to section 90-61, the difference in such amount shall be refundable by the city to the taxpayer or, if such business continues to be conducted in the city during the current year, such difference in amount may be credited by the city on the amount of occupation tax to be paid to the city by such business for the current year. (Code 1976, § 17-26) Sec. 90-66. - Returns confidential. Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax levied in this article, it shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, agent or clerk of the city or any other person to divulge or make known in any manner the amount of gross receipts or any particulars set forth or disclosed in any occupation tax return required under this article. All contents of such return shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents or clerks of the city using such returns for the purpose of the occupation tax levy and the collection of such tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classed as employees. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the publication by the city officials of statistics classified so as to prevent the identification of particular reports or returns, and items thereof, or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the state or the United States and other local governments. Information provided by a business or practitioner may be disclosed to the governing authority of another local government for occupational tax purposes. (Code 1976, § 17-27) Sec. 90-67. - Inspection of books and records. In any case, the city clerk, through his officers, agents, employees or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which a return is made. The city marshal and/or the director of the finance department or his designee shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made within the city, and upon demand of the city marshal and/or the director of the finance department or his designee, such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days of such demand. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax certificate currently existing to do business within the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the city marshal and/or the director of the finance department or his designee, at his discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of ten percent of the deficiency, and an additional one percent of the deficiency for each month, or fraction thereof, that the deficiency was due and unpaid, shall be assessed. (Code 1976, § 17-28) Sec. 90-68. - Tax certificate to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file returns or permit inspection of books. Except for persons whose qualifications to practice their profession is determined by the general laws of the state, the failure of any business to pay such occupation tax, or any part thereof, before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to permit inspection of such business' books as provided in section 17-28, any business tax certificate granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of such business to do business within the city for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax certificate shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax provided for in this article is, at that time, unpaid, or to a person who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the city marshal in accordance with provisions found in section 90-61. (Code 1976, § 17-29) Sec. 90-69. - Effect of failure to comply with article provisions. The following shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 90-79: (1) Any person or his manager, agent or employee who does business within the city after the certificate for such business has been revoked as provided for in section 90-68; (2) Any person or his manager, agent or employee required by this article to make returns showing the amount of gross receipts who shall fail to make such returns within the time and in the manner provided in this article, or refuses to amend such returns so as to set forth the correct information, or who shall make false returns; and (3) Any person or his manager, agent or employee who refuses to permit an inspection of books in their charge when the officer, agent, employee or representative of the city requests such inspection, during business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns provided for in this article. (Code 1976, § 17-30) Sec. 90-70. - Execution for delinquency. In addition to the other remedies provided in this article for the collection of the occupation tax levied in this article, the city clerk, upon any tax or installment of such tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of such tax against the person liable for such tax, which execution shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property of the person liable for such tax, all as provided by the ordinances and Charter of the city and the laws of the state. The lien for such occupation tax shall become fixed on and dated from the time when such tax, or any installment thereof, becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the city marshal upon the property of the person liable for such tax, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of such execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as provided by the ordinances and the Charter of the city and the laws of the state, and the defendant in such execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the Charter of the city and the laws of the state in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city marshal against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution was issued pays the tax in full, together with all interest, penalties and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due the person as though the person had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. (Code 1976, § 17-31) Sec. 90-71. - Exemptions. Any person 65 years of age or over shall be exempt from the payment of a business or occupation tax, provided such person shall, on or before April 1 each year, file a claim for such exemption and, provided further, the applicant for such exemption is the sole owner of the business for which the exemption is sought and is the sole employee thereof, and such person makes insufficient income to render him liable for state income taxes. The claim for exemption shall be filed on forms furnished by the city. The applicant shall be required to verify, under oath, the representations made in the application for the granting of such exemption. (Code 1976, § 17-32) Sec. 90-72. - Amendments or repeals. This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the board of commissioners to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed by this article. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation, and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for in this article shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property or business. (Code 1976, § 17-33) Sec. 90-73. - Application to prior ordinances. This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions of this article, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee or assessment shall be fully paid. (Code 1976, § 17-34) Sec. 90-74. - Enforcement. (a) It is hereby made the duty of the city marshal, city clerk and police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed, and to summon all violators of this article to appear before the municipal court. (b) It is hereby further made the duty of the city marshal, chief of police and their designees and assistants to inspect all certificates issued by the city as often as, in their judgement, it may seem necessary to determine whether the certificate held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted under such certificate. (Code 1976, § 17-35) Sec. 90-75. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by the board of commissioners. (a) This article shall remain in full force and effect until it is changed by amendment adopted by the board of commissioners. (b) All provisions of this article relating to any form of tax levied in this article shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. (Code 1976, § 17-36) Sec. 90-76. - Public hearing required before tax increase. After January 1, 1996, the board of commissioners shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. (Code 1976, § 17-37) Sec. 90-77. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in tax. By subsequent ordinance or resolution, the board of commissioners may provide for an exemption or reduction in the occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations and professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations and professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious. (Code 1976, § 17-38) Sec. 90-78. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention of this section that the specific shall control. (Code 1976, § 17-39) Sec. 90-79. - Violations; penalties. Any person violating any provision of this article, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11, except that any person whose qualifications to practice their profession is determined by the general laws of the state, and who fails to pay an occupation tax as provided in this article shall only be subject to the provisions of section 90-51(b). (Code 1976, § 17-18) Secs. 90-80—90-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
Sec. 90-111. - Business license tax levied. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 49-9-93, for the year 1995 and every year thereafter, there is hereby levied a business license tax from every financial institution located within the city, which shall be based upon 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of such depository financial institutions, as defined and allocated in this section, with a minimum annual tax of $1,000.00. (1) For the purposes of this section, the term "gross receipts" means the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized in subsections (a)(2) and (3) of this section during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax authorized by this section shall be due. Before determining gross receipts, there shall be deducted: a. An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; b. An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to title 7, chapter 1, article 5A of the Domestic International Banking Facility Act; c. An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; d. An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than this state; and e. To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (a)(1)b., c. and d. of this section, any deductions taken under subsection (a)(1)a. of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (a)(1)b.—d. of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (a)(1)a.—d. of this section. (2) The items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts, with respect to banks, are as follows: a. Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on the portions of loans sold and serviced for others; b. Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; c. Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under an agreement to resell; d. Interest on other bonds, notes and debentures, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; e. Dividends on stock; f. Income from direct lease financing; g. Income from fiduciary activities; h. Service charges on deposit accounts; i. Other service charges, commissions and fees; and j. Other income. (3) The items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts, with respect to savings and loan associations, are as follows: a. Interest on mortgage loans, less any interest collected on the portions of loans sold and serviced for others; b. Interest on mortgages, participation or mortgage backed securities; c. Interest on real estate sold on contract; d. Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; e. Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; f. Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; g. Loan fees; h. Loan servicing charges; i. Other fees and charges; j. Gross income from real estate and owned operations; k. Net income from office building operations; l. Gross income from real estate held for investment; m. Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; n. Miscellaneous operating income; o. Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans, and other assets; and p. Miscellaneous nonoperating income. (b) Every depository financial institution subject to the tax authorized under this section shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city by March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts are measured. Such returns shall be in the manner and form prescribed by the city, based on the allocation method set forth in subsection (d) of this section. The return shall provide the information necessary to determine the portion of the taxpayer's total gross receipts to be allocated to each taxing jurisdiction in which such institution has a place of business. The tax collected by the city shall be based upon the information provided in the returns. (c) The total gross receipts generated in the state by a depository financial institution subject to any tax authorized by this section shall be allocated among separate taxing jurisdictions as follows: (1) If a depository financial institution shall have an office or a place of business in more than one municipality, the amount of gross receipts taxable by each municipality shall be the amount of gross receipts attributable to such offices or places of business as of December 31 of the year in which gross receipts are measured; (2) If a depository financial institution shall have an office or a place of business in more than one county, the amount of gross receipts taxable by each county shall be the amount of gross receipts attributable to such offices or places of business as of December 31 of the year in which gross receipts are measured; and (3) In determining the amount of gross receipts attributable to each location, 20 percent of the gross receipts shall be attributable to the parent bank. The remaining 80 percent of gross receipts shall be attributable to branch banks and bank offices, pro rata, according to the number of such branch banks and bank offices, with none of the gross receipts attributable to bank facilities or other outlets not considered to be a parent bank, branch bank or bank office. As used in this subsection, the terms "parent bank," "branch bank" and "bank office" have the same meaning as such terms are defined in title 7, chapter 1 of the Financial Institutions Code of Georgia. If there are fewer than five branch banks or bank offices in addition to the parent bank, the amount of gross receipts attributable to each such parent bank, branch bank or bank office shall be determined by dividing the total gross receipts by the aggregate number of such outlets. For purposes of this distribution formula only, the term "bank" also means a savings and loan association. (Code 1976, § 17-50) Sec. 90-112. - Occupation tax for insurance companies. This article in no way affects the occupation tax on insurance companies and/or agents presently in effect and governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq., which existing ordinances shall continue in full force and effect. (Code 1976, § 17-51) Secs. 90-113—90-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE COMPANIES[3]

Sec. 90-131. - Insurers license fees. There is hereby levied for the year 2014 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the City of Jesup, Georgia, in the amount of $75.00. For each separated business location in excess of one not covered by section 90-132, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the City of Jesup, Georgia, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $75.00. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Code 1976, § 17-60; Ord. of 7-16-2013, § 1, eff. 1-1-2014) Sec. 90-132. - License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization, which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $26.25 per location for the year 2014 and for each year thereafter. (Code 1976, § 17-61; Ord. of 7-16-2013, § 2, eff. 1-1-2014) Editor's note— Section 2 of an ordinance adopted July 16, 2013, changed the title of § 90-132 from "Insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations" to "License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations." Sec. 90-133. - Independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. There is hereby levied for the year 1996 and each year thereafter, an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers, for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted, and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 90-131, in the amount as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk, for each such location within the city. (Code 1976, § 17-62) Sec. 90-134. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 2014 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 90-131 of this article. (Code 1976, § 17-63; Ord. of 7-16-2013, § 3, eff. 1-1-2014) Sec. 90-135. - Gross premiums tax; all other insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 2014 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated by O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to two and one-half percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 90-131 of this article. Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq.; local excise taxes on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.
Sec. 90-171. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows: City. The City of Jesup and, variously, the incorporated territory of Jesup, wherein the city government is empowered to impose this tax by OCGA 48-13-50, et seq. City clerk. The duly appointed city clerk of the city or his designee. Due date. The 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. Estimated tax liability. The lodging provider's prospective tax liability based upon the average monthly tax remittance in the prior fiscal year, as adjusted for change in tax rate or substantial change in circumstances due to damage to the hotel. Folio. Primary documentation produced by a hotel that demonstrates interaction between the lodging provider and the occupant, and which, at a minimum, reflects the name and address given by the occupant, the date(s) of occupancy, the amount of rent charged for each date together with the amounts of applicable excise tax(es), and the method(s) of payment. Guest room. Accommodations occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for transient occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. Hotel. Any facility or any portion of a facility, including any lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto or trailer court, truckstop, tourist cabin, campground, lodge, inn, time-share or other condominium, apartment community, public club, or private club, containing guest rooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by paying guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. It does not include any hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, jail, prison, or other facility in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. Lodging provider. Any person operating a hotel in the city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sub-lessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person operating such hotel; and who is subject to the taxation imposed for furnishing for value to the public any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations. Monthly period. The calendar months of any year. Occupancy. The use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any guest room in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the guest room. Occupant. Any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guest room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. Permanent resident. Any occupant who, as of a given date, has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel for not less than ten continuous days next preceding such date. Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, joint adventure, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, cooperative, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number; excepting the United States, the State of Georgia and any instrumentality of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax. Rent. The consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the lodging provider to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Tax. The tax on occupants imposed by this article, as provided for by O.C.G.A. 48-13-50, et seq., specifically 48-13-51(a)(3). (Ord. of 11-21-2006, § 1) Sec. 90-172. - Tax rate. There shall be paid for every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel in the city a tax at the rate of five percent of the amount of rent unless an exemption is provided under section 90-174. (Ord. of 11-21-2006, § 2) Sec. 90-173. - Collection of tax by lodging provider. Every lodging provider furnishing guest rooms in a hotel in the city shall collect a tax of five percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exception is provided under section 90-174. The lodging provider shall provide a receipt to each occupant, which receipt shall reflect both the amount of rent and the amounts of this and other tax(es) applicable. This tax shall be due from the occupant, and shall be collected by the lodging provider at the same time that the rent is collected. The lodging provider shall be liable for any amount of tax that he fails to collect appropriately; and must remit to the city any amount of tax collected in excess of that which should have been collected. (Ord. of 11-21-2006, § 3) Sec. 90-174. - Exceptions. No tax shall be collected from an occupant after becoming a permanent resident; or from an occupant who certifies in writing that he is staying in such accommodations as a result of his residence having been destroyed by fire or other casualty; or from the United States and the State of Georgia or any instrumentality of either thereof; or from any official or employee of the state, its units of local government or any other instrumentality of the state, when traveling on official business and presenting written substantiation thereof or paying by state or local government credit or debit card; or from a foreign diplomat enjoying exemption by treaty or consular convention, when presenting substantiation issued by the United States, Department of State. Occupancy provided without charge in money or otherwise is not subject to this tax. (Ord. of 11-21-2006, § 4) Sec. 90-175. - Registration of lodging provider; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. Every person engaging or about to engage in business as a lodging provider in the city shall immediately register with the city clerk on a form provided by said official. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than 30 days after the date that this article becomes effective. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place(s) of business and such other information which would facilitate the administration of the tax as prescribed by the city clerk. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The city clerk shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each lodging provider to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of a lodging provider. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. (Ord. of 11-21-2006, § 5) Sec. 90-176. - Determination generally; returns; payments. (a) Due date of taxes. All amounts of such tax shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the 20th day of the month next succeeding the respective monthly period. The tax shall become delinquent for any monthly period after the 20th day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. (b) Penalty and interest for failure to pay tax by due date. A lodging provider who fails to make any return or to pay the amount of tax as prescribed, shall be assessed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for one month or less; and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof in which such failure shall continue; provided, however, that the aggregate penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00, whichever is greater. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. (c) Acceptance of delinquent return and remittance without imposing penalty and interest; authority; requirements. If the failure to make any return or to pay the amount of tax by the due date results from providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the governing authority of the city by affidavit attached to the return, and remittance is made within ten days of the due date, such return may be accepted exclusive of penalty and interest. (d) Waiving of penalty and interest; authority. O.C.G.A. § 48-2-41, relating to the authority to waive interest, and § 48-2-43, relating to the authority to waive penalty, shall apply; provided, however, that the governing authority shall stand in lieu of the Georgia Commissioner of Revenue, and the city shall stand in lieu of the state. (e) Penalty for fraud. In the case of a false or fraudulent return, or of failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the city of any tax due, a penalty of 50 percent shall be assessed. (f) Return; remittance; time of filing; lodging providers required to file; contents. On or before the 20th day of the month succeeding each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period together with appropriate remittance shall be filed with the city clerk. The return shall report the gross rent, taxable rent, exempt rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. However, if the estimated tax liability for any monthly period shall exceed $2,500.00 for a lodging provider who, in the prior fiscal year remitted tax greater than $2,500.00 in any three consecutive months, such lodging provider shall file an estimated return and remit not less than 50 percent of the estimated tax liability for the monthly period by the 20th day of that same monthly period.
