Federal aviation administration or FAA means the government agency responsible for regulating civil aviation. Federal Communications Commission or FCC means the government agency responsible for regulating telecommunications. Small cell installations means one-carrier units that provide additional capacity for wireless systems and are supplemental to standard wireless telecommunications facility installations. Wireless support structure means a freestanding structure designed to support or capable of supporting wireless facilities. Wireless telecommunication facility or WTF means the set of equipment and network components, exclusive of the underlying support structure, including antennas, transmitters, receivers, base stations, power supplies, cabling, and accessory equipment, used to provide wireless data and wireless telecommunication services. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-137. - Applicability and exemptions. (a) Applicability. This article shall apply to the installation, construction, or modification of the following wireless telecommunication facilities: (1) Existing antenna support structures; (2) Proposed antenna support structures; (3) Replacement and modification of existing antenna support structures; (4) Collocation or combining on existing antenna support structures; (5) Distributed antennae systems; (6) Attached wireless telecommunication facilities; (7) Concealed wireless telecommunication facilities; and (8) Small cell. (b) Exemptions. The following uses are exempt from the requirements of this article notwithstanding any other land development provision, hut are subject to all applicable building code compliance and building permit reviews: (1) Non-commercial, amateur radio antennas; (2) Single-use local radio dispatch; (3) Television antennas for home reception use; (4) Satellite earth stations that are under one meter (39.37 inches) or less in diameter in all residential districts and two meters or less in all other zoning districts; (5) Antenna support structures, antennas and/or antenna arrays for AM/FM/TV/HDTV broadcasting transmission facilities that are licenses by the FCC; (6) A temporary, commercial WTF, upon the declaration of emergency by federal, state, or local government, or determination of public necessity by the city, and approval by the city manager; except that such WTF must comply with all federal and state requirements. The exemption may continue up to 120 days after the duration of the state of emergency with the approval of the city manager; and (7) A temporary, commercial WTF for the purposes of providing coverage of a special event such as news coverage or sporting event, subject to approval of the city manager, except that such WTF must comply with all federal and state requirements. The exemption may continue up to seven days after the duration of the special event. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-138. - Permit application requirements. An application for a WTF shall include the applicable items listed in this section, in addition to other requirements within this article. (1) Authorization from co-applicants. For all facilities, all parties with an ownership interest, including the land owner, support structure owner, and facility owner shall be co-applicants and be bound by and comply with all terms, limitations, requirements, and conditions that are part of this article and of any permit issued. The WTF applicant shall provide signed authorization from co-applicants allowing the application. (2) Site plan. For new wireless support structures and when a proposed WTF will create a site modification, a site plan (no larger than 24 inches by 36 inches with an eight and one-half-inch by 11-inch reduced copy) prepared and certified by a Georgia licensed professional engineer shall include all information listed on the WTF application checklist. Other site plan related information shall include: a. Existing and proposed access. Existing or proposed public rights-of-way, private roads and/or access easements through, on, or adjacent to the subject property. The proposed access driveway or roadway and parking area at the WTF site shall be shown, to include grading, drainage and traveled width and type of surface materials proposed; b. Landscape plan. Any proposed modification to the landscape, including altering the method of irrigation and any proposed removal of vegetation, shall be identified; c. Drainage. Plans for drainage of surface and sub-surface water to control erosion and sedimentation both during construction and as a permanent measure; and d. Utilities. Proposed utilities, including distance from power source, sizes of service available and required, locations of any proposed utility or telecommunications lines, and whether utilities will be above ground or underground. e. Zoning ordinance. Compliance with zoning regulations contained in the revised zoning ordinance of the City of Jesup, Georgia, shall be demonstrated. (3) WTF plan. For all WTFs, a plan (no larger than 24 inches by 36 inches with an eight and one-half-inch by 11-inch reduced copy) shall include a diagram of the proposed facility and antenna(s), including: a. Elevation of the antenna and/or antenna support structure to include the following proposed dimensions: height, width, and breadth. Height shall include the base, the antenna support structure, and lightning rod; b. Elevation views of the security barrier or equipment compound, indicating architectural design, exterior appearance and materials, including color; c. Mounting location on antenna support structure or building, including height (AGL); d. If a concealed or nonconcealed attached WTF is proposed, identification of all mounting frames, arms, brackets or other devices or equipment used to hold antennas and other equipment in place; e. Equipment brochures or drawings for the proposed facility, shall be provided for antennas, support structures/mounts, equipment shelters, feed lines and security barrier, if any; and (4) Documentation from applicable regulatory agencies. For all WTFs, copies of all applicable licenses or approvals, if available, as required by the FCC and any other agency of the government with authority to regulate WTFs to include the following at the time of submission: a. A copy of Form 600 on file with the FCC; or FCC license (radio authorization form); b. Evidence of compliance with applicable FAA requirements under 14 C.F.R. 77, et seq., as amended, which may be a copy of the FAA notice of proposed construction; and c. A compliance letter from the Historic Preservation Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. (5) Interference study. For all WTFs, a letter from a radio frequency engineer shall be provided certifying the proposed WTFs will not interfere with public safety emergency communications. (6) Radio frequency engineer qualifications. For all WTFs, a curriculum vitae shall be provided for the radio frequency engineer who certifies any documentation provided as part of the application for a WTF. Information shall include education obtained in the area of radio frequency engineering, and experience in the field, including length of time. (7) Structural engineering study. A structural engineering study carried out by a qualified structural engineer shall be submitted, showing that the wireless support structure(s) is (are) able to support the proposed WTFs. If the study finds that any proposed structure is inadequate to support the proposed antenna loads, the city may decline to permit installation. (8) Fees. In addition to any other fees required by the city, applicants shall pay a fee to cover the actual cost and the administrative fee for consulting services that may be required by the city and/or MPC to evaluate any technical aspect of the WTF application. (9) Address. Applicants and co-applicants shall keep the city manager informed of their current mailing address and shall advise the city manager of any change in mailing address within 30 days of such change. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-139. - Additional standards for issuance of permit. (a) Setbacks. All WTFs and their equipment enclosures and ancillary structures shall comply with the setback provisions of the zoning district in which the WTF is located. (b) Lighting and signage. (1) Wireless telecommunications facilities taller than 199 feet AGL shall be lit according to FAA standards, including light intensity and flashes per minute. When applicable, dual lighting systems shall be employed. This dual lighting system includes red lights (L-864) for nighttime and medium intensity flashing white lights (L-865) for daytime and twilight use. This lighting system may be used in lieu of operating a medium intensity flashing white light system at night. (2) Wireless support structures between 100 and 199 feet AGL shall be equipped with: a. Dual lighting system includes red lights (L-864) for nighttime and medium intensity flashing white lights (L-865) for daytime and twilight use; and b. White reflective tape/sheeting installed at 20 feet AGL on all nonconcealed freestanding WTFs and continuing upward at ten-foot intervals. (3) Lighting of equipment enclosures and other ancillary structures on site shall be shielded from adjacent properties. The footcandle measurement at property lines shall be no more than 1.0 footcandle when measured at grade. FAA required lighting is exempt from this requirement. (4) Signs shall be limited to those needed to identify the WTF, the owner, the party responsible for the operation and maintenance (including address and telephone number), to warn of danger, and to comply with applicable federal regulations. Such signage shall be visible and legible at ground level. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-140. - Modifications. (a) A modification is a proposed change to any portion of a WTF from its description in a previously approved permit that: (1) Increases the overall height or width of the wireless support structure to which the WTFs are to be attached; (2) Increases the dimensions of the equipment compound initially approved by the city; (b) All proposed modifications and colocations shall comply with all applicable conditions and provisions of the existing permit and all applicable standards of this article. (c) All proposed modifications and colocations shall not exceed the applicable weight limits for the wireless support structure, as demonstrated by a letter from a structural engineer licensed to practice in this state. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-141. - Permit application review. (a) The city shall have the right to reject a permit application if, in its discretion, the use under the circumstances is unsafe or overly and unduly burdens city property or the wireless support structure. (b) In assessing permit applications for the construction and installation of new wireless support structures, the city will consider siting and location, height, setbacks, aesthetics and visibility, environmental standards, safety standards and other relevant factors related to the city's desire to encourage location and collocation and the orderly development of telecommunications infrastructure. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-142. - Permit application processing. (a) Application for modification or collocation. (1) Within 30 calendar days of the date an application for modification or collocation is filed with the city, the city shall determine if it is a complete application and, if it determines the application is not a complete application, notify the applicant in writing of any information required to complete such application. a. To the extent additional information is required to complete the application, the time required by the applicant to provide such information shall not be counted toward the 90 calendar day review period set forth in subsection (a)(2) of this Code section. b. Information requested to complete the application may only include the documents, information, and fees specifically enumerated in the city's regulations, ordinances, and forms pertaining to the location, construction, collocation, modification, or operation of WTFs. (2) Within 90 calendar days of the date an application for modification or collocation of wireless facilities is filed with the city, unless another date is specified in a written agreement between the city and the applicant, the city shall make its final decision to approve or disapprove the application; and advise the applicant in writing of its final decision. (b) Application for a new wireless support structure or wireless telecommunications facility. (1) Within 30 calendar days of the date an application for a new wireless support structure or WTF is filed with the city, the city shall determine if it is a complete application and, if it determines the application is not a complete application, notify the applicant in writing of any information required to complete such application. a. To the extent additional information is required to complete the application, the time required by the applicant to provide such information shall not be counted toward the calendar day review period set forth in subsection (b)(2) of this Code section. b. Information requested to complete the application may only include the documents, information, and fees specifically enumerated in the city's regulations, ordinances, and forms pertaining to the location, construction, collocation, modification, or operation of WTFs. (2) Within 150 calendar days of the date an application for a new wireless support structure or WTF is filed with the city, unless another date is specified in a written agreement between the city and the applicant, the city shall make its final decision to approve or disapprove the application; and advise the applicant in writing of its final decision. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1) Sec. 98-143. - Zoning requirements. All applicable zoning procedures must be followed and all zoning regulations must be satisfied as provided in the revised zoning ordinance of the City of Jesup, Georgia. (Ord. of 11-28-2017, § 1)

div.head: Chapter 102 - VEGETATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; weeds, rubbish, brush, trash, etc., § 38-31; manufactured homes, ch. 62; planning and zoning, ch. 70; streets and sidewalks, ch. 86; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 102-1—102-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARK AND TREE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 102-31. - Established. A park and tree department is hereby established as a part of the departmental organization of the city. (Code 1976, § 2-121) Sec. 102-32. - Department head. The park and tree department shall be under the direction of the director of public works who shall be appointed by, and be responsible to, the city manager. (Code 1976, § 2-122) Secs. 102-33—102-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TREE BOARD
Sec. 102-61. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and vines within the city. (Code 1976, § 2-134) Sec. 102-62. - Creation; appointment; membership; staggered terms; meetings. (a) The city tree board shall be composed of seven members. Each commissioner from each commission district will appoint one member, totaling six members, and the mayor will appoint one additional member, to comprise the seven-member board. The appointed members shall be registered voters of the city. No member of the tree board shall be persons who hold elected public office in the city or Wayne County, Georgia. Appointments to the tree board shall be for overlapping terms of three years with terms expiring on December 31. With the exception of those appointments addressed in subsection (b) of this section, the regular initial appointments to the tree board which first occur after the passage of this section (which such initial appointments shall occur after the expiration of the current terms of the members of the tree board expire) shall be made so that the terms of said members shall be staggered. In order to establish staggered terms, the initial terms of two members shall be one year, and the initial terms of another two members will be two years, and the initial terms of another three members will be for three years. The members serving the one-year terms, the two-year terms, and the three-year terms shall be determined by agreement of the board of commissioners of the city and mayor or by lot in the absence of such agreement. If at the end of any term of office of a member, a successor thereto shall not have been appointed, then the member whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until his or her successor shall be so appointed. Any vacancy in the tree board shall be filled by appointment by the commissioner or mayor who made the original appointment to the tree board that is then vacant. In the event of the absence or vacancy of the commissioner or mayor who made such original appointment to the tree board, any such vacancy in the tree board shall be appointed by an affirmative majority vote of the remaining commissioners and the mayor. Members of the tree board can serve successive terms without limit. The members of the tree board shall receive no compensation for their services, and shall at all times maintain a current mailing address and telephone number on file with the city. (b) Following the passage of this section, the board of commissioners will make any additional appointments to such board necessitated by the increase in the number of the members of such board under this section by a majority vote of the commissioners and mayor. (c) The board of commissioners of the city shall be authorized to remove any member for cause after written notice and public hearing. Any one or more of the following shall constitute a reason for removing a member "for cause": (1) Participating as a member of the tree board at any regular or called meeting of the tree board under the influence of intoxicants, alcohol, or unprescribed or illegal drugs or using, possessing or selling the same in violation of the laws of the State of Georgia; (2) Charge and accusation for a misdemeanor which would adversely affect performance of his or her duties as a member of the tree board; (3) Conduct unbecoming of a member of the tree board, including, but not limited to, demeaning conduct or use of profanity or vulgar language during any open public meeting of the tree board; (4) Indictment of a felony; (5) Unauthorized use of city property, city telephones or other city communication equipment; (6) Filing false expense reports; (7) Three consecutive absences from tree board meetings without obtaining prior approval of a majority of the remaining members of the tree board; or (8) Repeated and continued discourteous treatment of members of the public during tree board meetings after being admonished concerning such conduct by the board of commissioners of the city. Charges for "removable for cause" may be made by any city commissioner, any member of the tree board or by any citizen of the city. Any such charges must be made in writing, dated, signed and delivered to the board of commissioners of the city. A copy of any such charge must be mailed to the person making the charge to the member of the tree board against whom the charge is directed. Upon receipt of any such charge the board of commissioners of the city will then set a date and time for a public hearing. The city manager will notify both the party making the charge and the member of the tree board against whom the charges are directed of the date, time and place of the public hearing. The member of the tree board against whom charges are made shall have at least two weeks notice prior to the date set for the public hearing to prepare for the public hearing. In the event, after the public hearing, the board of commissioners of the city, by majority vote, removes the member of the tree board, the board of commissioners of the city will then proceed to fill the vacancy for the unexpired term pursuant to the foregoing provisions of this section. (d) Ex officio members shall be: (1) one member of the board of commissioners of the city as selected by the mayor, (2) the city employee responsible for planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and vines on city property (presently the superintendent of streets and sanitation or his or her representative), and (3) the Wayne County, Georgia Forester. (e) During the first month after being appointed after the passage of this section, and at the first meeting after July 1 of each year, the tree board shall elect: (1) a chairman, (2) a vice-chairman and (3) a secretary-treasurer from among its appointed members. (f) The tree board shall meet at least once during each quarter of the year during January, April, July and October. Additional meetings may be held as requested by the chairman. A quorum shall consist of three appointed members. If the chairman or vice-chairman is not present, the members present, by majority vote, shall designate one of the members to serve as acting chairman for that meeting. (g) During June of each year, the tree board shall submit a report on its activities during the past year to the board of commissioners of the city. (Code 1976, § 2-135; Ord. No. 2017-006, § 1, 2-7-2017) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-006, § 1, adopted Feb. 7, 2017, changed the title of § 102-62 from "Created; membership; compensation; term of office; officers; meetings; activities report" to read as herein set out. Sec. 102-63. - Powers and authority. The tree board created in this article shall have the power and authority to: (1) Determine the needs of the city for the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and vines on city property. (2) Formulate a tree ordinance which will specify rules and regulations pertaining to trees, shrubs and vines as needed by the board in the performance of its duties, subject to approval by the board of commissioners. (3) Investigate the presence of hazardous or diseased trees, shrubs and vines on private property which may be a threat to the public safety or the trees and shrubs on nearby properties. (4) Specify requirements for persons engaged in the business of planting, maintenance and removal of trees within the city. (5) Prepare rules for the landscaping and removal and planting of trees and shrubs in new housing subdivisions and commercial property developments. (6) Offer recommendations for tree, shrub and vine plantings and maintenance on private property. (7) Submit to the board of commissioners for approval all rules, regulations, standards, specifications and requirements, and all revisions thereto, as prepared and recommended by the board. (8) Review all requests for variances from the approved rules, standards, specifications and requirements, and make recommendations to the board of commissioners pertaining thereto. (9) Report to the city manager and/or board of commissioners regarding its findings and recommendations. (Code 1976, § 2-136) Secs. 102-64—102-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - TREES
Sec. 102-91. - Intent. The intent of this article is to establish regulations for trees, shrubs and vines in the public areas of the city in order to better control problems with flooding, soil conservation, air pollution and noise within the city, and to make the city a healthier, safer and more beautiful place in which to live. (Code 1976, § 20-110) Sec. 102-92. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Crown spread means the distance measured across the greatest diameter of a plant. Park trees means either evergreen or deciduous trees, shrubs or vines on land designated as public park land owned by the city, or land to which the public has free access as a park. Shade trees means any self-supporting woody plant of a species that is well-shaped, well-branched and well-foliated, which normally grows to an overall height of at least 35 feet and normally develops an average mature crown spread greater than 30 feet within the city. Street trees means either evergreen or deciduous trees, shrubs or vines on land lying between the public right-of-way and private property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or ways within the city. (Code 1976, § 20-111) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 102-93. - Inventory. A listing of street, park, shade and small trees approved by the tree board for planting shall be maintained by the office of the city manager. (Code 1976, § 20-112) Sec. 102-94. - Planting distance from street corners and fireplugs. (a) No street tree shall be planted closer than 30 feet to any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. However, shrubs maintained less than three feet in height are acceptable. (b) No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet to any fireplug. (Code 1976, § 20-113) Sec. 102-95. - Planting distance from utilities. No street tree, other than the species listed as small trees in this article, may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, power line or other utility. (Code 1976, § 20-114) Sec. 102-96. - Public tree care; right to remove unsafe trees. (a) The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants, shrubs and vines within the lines of streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary, to ensure public safety and preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. (b) The city shall have the right to remove, or cause or order to be removed, any tree, or part thereof, which is in an unsafe condition, or which, by reason of its nature, is injurious to sewers, electrical power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. (Code 1976, § 20-115) Sec. 102-97. - Topping; exemptions. (a) It shall be unlawful, as a normal practice, for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. For the purposes of this section, the term "topping" means the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. (b) Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires where other pruning practices are impractical, shall be exempt from this section. (Code 1976, § 20-116) Sec. 102-98. - Pruning. (a) Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches of such tree so that the branches shall not obstruct the light from any streetlamp or the view of any street intersection, and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Such owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. (b) The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or visibility of any traffic control device or sign. (Code 1976, § 20-117) Sec. 102-99. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased tree on private property within the city when such tree constitutes a hazard to life and property or harbors insects or disease which constitutes a potential threat to other trees within the city. Whenever the city tree board determines that such a dead or diseased tree exists within the city, they shall notify the property owner in writing, giving such owner 60 days' notice from the date of service to have such tree removed. Failure of the owner to comply with such provisions or order of the city tree board to remove such tree shall constitute a violation of this article, which shall be punishable as defined in section 1-11. The city shall also have the authority to remove such tree and place a lien on the property in the same manner as for taxes in order to cover the cost of such removal. (Code 1976, § 20-118) Sec. 102-100. - Stump removal. All street and park tree stumps shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. (Code 1976, § 20-119) Sec. 102-101. - Interference with city. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city or any of its agents while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street tree, park tree or tree on private grounds, as authorized in this article. (Code 1976, § 20-120) Sec. 102-102. - Violation; penalty. Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11. (Code 1976, § 20-121)

div.head: Chapter 106 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22; streets and sidewalks, ch. 86; traffic, ch. 94. State Law reference— Reciprocal agreements as to operation of vehicles registered in other states inapplicable to motor vehicles for hire, O.C.G.A. § 40-2-95.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 106-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Cruising means the driving of a taxicab on the streets, alleys or public roads of the city in search of, or soliciting, prospective passengers for hire. Driver's license means the permission granted by the board of commissioners to a person to drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city. Holder means a person to whom a certificate of public convenience and necessity has been issued. Open stand means a public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere within the city, which has been designated by the board of commissioners as reserved exclusively for the use of taxicabs. Rate card means a card issued by the board of commissioners for display in each taxicab which contains the rate of fare then in force. Taxicab means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, having a seating capacity of less than six persons, and not operated on a fixed route. (Code 1976, § 33-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 106-2. - Scope of taxicab service. All persons engaged in the taxicab business within the city, operating under the provisions of this chapter, shall render an overall service to the public desiring to use taxicabs. Such persons shall maintain a central place of business and keep the business open for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching cabs. Such persons shall answer calls received by them for services inside the corporate limits of the city as soon as they can do so, and if such services cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall then notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the call can be answered and give the reasons therefor. Any taxicab operator who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere within the corporate limits of the city at any time when such holder has available cabs, or who shall fail or refuse to give overall service, shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. (Code 1976, § 33-1.1) Sec. 106-3. - Rate cards. All taxicabs operating under this chapter shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed in such a place as to be in view of the passengers of such taxicabs. (Code 1976, § 33-2) Sec. 106-4. - Receipts. Upon demand by the passenger, the taxicab driver shall render to such passenger a receipt for the amount charged, on which receipt the name of the owner, license number or motor number, amount of charges and date of transaction shall appear. (Code 1976, § 33-3) Sec. 106-5. - Refusal to pay legal fare. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab after having hired the taxicab; and it shall be unlawful for any person to hire any taxicab with the intent to defraud the person from whom such taxicab is hired of the value of such service. (Code 1976, § 33-4) Sec. 106-6. - Solicitations generally. No driver shall solicit passengers for a taxicab, except when sitting in the driver's compartment of such taxicab or while standing immediately adjacent to the curbside thereof. The driver of any taxicab shall remain in the driver's compartment or immediately adjacent to his vehicle at all times when such vehicle is upon the streets, except that, when necessary, a driver may be absent from his taxicab for not more than 15 minutes and, provided further, that nothing contained in this section shall be held to prohibit any driver from alighting to the street or sidewalk for the purpose of assisting passengers into or out of the taxicab. (Code 1976, § 33-5) Sec. 106-7. - Prohibited solicitations. No driver shall solicit patronage in a loud or annoying tone of voice or by sign, or in any manner annoy any person or obstruct the movement of any person, or follow any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage. (Code 1976, § 33-6) Sec. 106-8. - Solicitation of other common carrier passengers. No driver, owner or operator shall solicit passengers at the terminals of any other common carrier, nor at any intermediate points along the established route of any other common carrier. (Code 1976, § 33-7) Sec. 106-9. - Solicitation for other businesses. It shall be unlawful for the driver of a taxicab to solicit business for any hotel, roominghouse or motel, or attempt to divert patronage from one such establishment to another. (Code 1976, § 33-8) Sec. 106-10. - Cruising. No driver shall cruise in search of passengers, except in such areas, and at such times, as shall be designated when the police department finds that taxicab cruising would not congest traffic or be dangerous to pedestrians and other vehicles. (Code 1976, § 33-9) Sec. 106-11. - Receiving and discharging of passengers. Drivers of taxicabs shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway, but shall pull up to the righthand sidewalk, as nearly as possible, or in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme righthand side of the road and then receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets, where passengers may be discharged at either the righthand or lefthand sidewalk, or side of the roadway in the absence of a walk. (Code 1976, § 33-10) Sec. 106-12. - Number of passengers restricted; exception. No driver shall permit no more than five persons to be carried in a taxicab as passengers. A child in arms shall not be counted as a passenger. (Code 1976, § 33-11) Sec. 106-13. - Refusing or neglecting to carry orderly passengers. No driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless such driver is previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this chapter to do so. (Code 1976, § 33-12) Sec. 106-14. - Unlawful activities. It shall be unlawful for a taxicab driver to engage in selling or hauling intoxicating liquors, or solicit business for any house of ill repute, or use his vehicle for any purpose other than the transporting of passengers. (Code 1976, § 33-13) Sec. 106-15. - Advertising. Subject to the rules and regulations of the board of commissioners or the police department, it shall be lawful for any person owning or operating a taxicab or motor vehicle for hire to permit advertising matter to be affixed or installed in or on such taxicabs or motor vehicles for hire. (Code 1976, § 33-14) Secs. 106-16—106-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAXI PERMIT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ordinance of Feb. 7, 2012, deleted the former Art. II, §§ 106-51—106-54, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to license and derived from the Code of 1976, §§ 33-26, 33-21, §§ 33-30, 33-31)
Sec. 106-51. - Required. No person shall operate or permit a taxicab owned or controlled by him to be operated as a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city without having first obtained a taxi permit to do so as provided in the occupation tax provisions of this Code (chapter 90, article II). (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-52. - Application. An application for a taxi permit under this article shall be filed with the city clerk upon forms provided by the city, and such application shall be verified under oath, and shall furnish the following information: (1) The name and address of the applicant. (2) The financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such judgments. (3) The applicant's experience in the transportation of passengers. (4) The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant, and the location of proposed depots and terminals. (5) A bona fide and accurate motor vehicle driver's license summary, DMV history or driver's license history of the applicant. (6) A complete criminal background history of the applicant. (7) Any facts which the applicant believes tends to prove that public convenience and necessity require the granting of a license. (8) Such further information as the board of commissioners may require. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-53. - Liability insurance. No taxi permit shall be issued or continued in operation unless there is in full force and effect a liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state for each authorized vehicle in such amount as required by state law. A copy of the insurance policy shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-54. - Permit fees. No taxi permit shall be issued or continued in operation unless the holder thereof has paid an annual permit fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for the right to engage in the taxicab business and an annual fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for each vehicle operated within the city. Such permit fees shall be for the fiscal year, and shall be in addition to any other license fees or charges established by proper authority and applicable to such vehicle under his operation and control. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Secs. 106-55—106-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CITY DRIVER'S PERMIT[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ordinance of Feb. 7, 2012, deleted the former Art. III, §§ 106-91—106-99, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to driver's license and derived from the Code of 1976, §§ 33-47—33-55.
Sec. 106-91. - Required. No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit such operation, and no taxicab licensed by the city shall be driven for hire at any time, unless the driver of such taxicab shall have first obtained and shall have in force at that time a taxicab driver's city permit issued under the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-92. - Application. (a) An application for a city driver's permit shall be filed with the city clerk on forms provided by the city, and such application shall be verified under oath, and shall contain the following information: (1) The names and addresses of four residents of the city who have known the applicant for a period of one year, and who will vouch for the sobriety, honesty and general good character of the applicant. (2) The applicant's experience in the transportation of passengers. (3) The educational background of the applicant. (4) A concise history of the applicant's employment. (5) A bona fide and accurate motor vehicle driver's license summary, DMV history or driver's license history of the applicant. (6) A complete criminal background history of the applicant. (7) Such other information as may be required by the clerk to enable him to determine whether or not such city permit shall be issued. (b) Before any city driver's permit is granted to such applicant, he shall be required to furnish a photograph of himself, in triplicate; one of such photographs to be pasted on the city driver's permit supplied by the city and will be placed in the automobile which he is to drive, where the photograph will be in clear view of the passengers, with his name under such photograph; one of such photographs shall be pasted on his city driver's permit, which he must always have on his person whenever driving a public motor vehicle; and the third photograph shall be filed at the city police headquarters with his application. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-93. - Examination; state license. Before any application for a city driver's permit required by this article is finally passed upon by the clerk, the applicant shall be required to pass a satisfactory examination as to his knowledge of the city, and to show that he has a current motor vehicle operator's license issued by the state. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-94. - Investigation. The police department shall conduct an investigation of each applicant for a city driver's permit, and a report of such investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application for the consideration of the clerk. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-95. - Approval or disapproval. Upon consideration of the application for a city driver's permit and the reports and certificates required to be attached thereto, the city clerk shall approve or disapprove the application. If the application is rejected, the applicant may request a personal appearance before the board of commissioners to offer evidence as to why his application should be considered. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-96. - Fee. Before any city driver's permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article, the applicant shall pay to the city a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-97. - Issuance. Upon approval of an application for a city driver's permit, the clerk shall issue a license to the applicant, which shall bear the name, address, color, age, signature and photograph of the applicant. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-98. - Duration of validity. Each taxicab driver's license issued under this article shall be valid for the fiscal year of the city. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Sec. 106-99. - Authority to suspend or revoke; report of violation. (a) The clerk is hereby given the authority to suspend any city driver's permit issued under this article for a driver's failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this chapter, which suspension shall last for a period of not more than 20 days. The board of commissioners are also given authority to revoke any city driver's permit for failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter. However, a city driver's permit may not be revoked unless the driver has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence in his behalf. (b) The chief of police is hereby directed to report any violation of this article, or the laws of the state or the United States to the board of commissioners, along with his recommendation. (Ord. of 2-7-2012) Secs. 106-100—106-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLES
Sec. 106-131. - Approval. Prior to the use and operation of any vehicle under the provisions of this chapter, such vehicle shall be thoroughly examined and inspected by the police department and found to comply with such reasonable rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the police department. The police department is hereby authorized to prescribe such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary for the safe operation of taxicabs within the city. Such rules and regulations shall be promulgated to provide safe transportation and shall specify such safety equipment and regulatory devices as the police department shall deem advisable to holders and drivers. (Code 1976, § 33-67) Sec. 106-132. - Periodic inspections. Every vehicle operating under this chapter shall be periodically inspected by the police department at such intervals as may be established by the police department to ensure the continued maintenance of safe operating conditions. (Code 1976, § 33-68) Sec. 106-133. - Clean and sanitary condition required. Every vehicle operating under this chapter must be kept clean and in a sanitary condition according to rules and regulations of the police department. (Code 1976, § 33-69) Sec. 106-134. - Condemnation for noncompliance; correction. When the inspection of any taxicab shall disclose that such vehicle does not comply with the intent of this chapter or the rules and regulations of the police department, the police department is authorized and directed to condemn such vehicle for use as a taxicab until such conditions are corrected. (Code 1976, § 33-70) Sec. 106-135. - Identification. Every public vehicle for hire or taxicab, however designated, shall have a sign plainly painted on the passenger door on each side of such vehicle, in letters not less than four inches high, the full name of the company or individual owning the vehicle and the term "TAXICAB," and in addition, there shall be painted on the passenger door on each side and on the rear a number at least six inches high, which shall be a separate and distinct number from that of any other public vehicle or taxicab within the city. Such number shall be assigned to such vehicle or taxicab and the owner thereof by the chief of police, and shall not be altered or changed without the consent of the chief of police. The number, together with the name of the owner as well as the operator of such vehicle or taxicab, shall be registered at the police department in a book to be kept by the chief of police for such purpose. (Code 1976, § 33-71) APPENDIX A - ZONING[1] REVISED ZONING ORDINANCE of the CITY OF JESUP, GEORGIA TITLE An ordinance regulating the location, height, bulk, number and the size of buildings and structures, the size of yards, courts and other open spaces, the density and distribution of population, the uses of buildings and structures and land for trade, industry, commerce, residence, recreation, public activities, or other purposes: Creating districts for said purposes and establishing the boundaries thereof.Defining certain terms used herein: Providing for the method of administration and amendment: Providing penalties for violation: Repealing conflicting ordinances: And for other purposes. Be it ordained by the Board of Commissioners for the City of Jesup: Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Printed herein is the city's zoning ordinance, as adopted by the board of commissioners on July 15, 1975.
