ARTICLE XII. - DESIGN STANDARDS FOR BLOCKS AND LOTS
Section 1201. - Block lengths and widths. Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: a. Blocks shall be not greater than 1,800 feet nor less than 600 feet in length, except in unusual circumstances. b. Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major streets, limited-access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. Section 1202. - Lot sizes. Residential lots shall meet the lot width and lot area requirements of the zoning ordinance. Residential lots shall have a depth of not less than 100 feet and not greater than two times the width of the lot at the building line, unless unusual circumstances make these limitations not practicable. Where individual septic tanks are used on residential lots served by an approved central water system, the lot size shall be no less than 12,000 square feet, and residential lots not served by an approved central water system shall be no less than 18,000 square feet in area or such greater area as the Wayne County Health Department may determine based upon boring for ground water level, soil data and soil percolation test, submitted for review. Commercial and industrial lots shall be adequate width to meet building setback requirements from both abutting streets. Section 1203. - Lot lines. All lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines, unless not practicable because of topographic or other features. Section 1204. - Building lines. A building line meeting the front yard setback requirements of the zoning ordinance shall be established on all lots. Section 1205. - Lots abutting public streets. Each lot shall abut upon a dedicated public street. Section 1206. - Double and reverse frontage lots. Double frontage, and reverse frontage lots, should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. ARTICLE XIII. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
Section 1301. - Required improvements. Prior to the granting of final approval, the subdivider shall have installed or shall have entered into a written contract with the City of Jesup providing for the ultimate installation of and compliance with the following: (a) Monuments shall be placed at all block corners, angle points, points of curves and streets, and at intermediate points, as required and determined by the city engineer. (b) All streets shall be staked, graded, based and prepared for paving in accordance with the applicable standard specifications of the city. (c) Drainage and drainage structures shall be provided in accordance with the standard specifications of the city. (d) Street signs shall be placed at all street intersections within or abutting the subdivision. Such signs shall be of a type approved by the city and shall be placed in accordance with the standards adopted by the city. (e) Sanitary sewer lines and manholes, conforming to standard specifications of the city, shall be installed where a public sanitary sewer line is reasonably accessible. Where such sanitary sewer lines and manholes are required, the subdivider shall be responsible for payment of all materials required for the installation of such sanitary sewer lines and manholes to and within the subdivision. The city shall provide the labor for the installation of the sewer lines and manholes where such work can be done with city employees and city-owned equipment and at such time as the city's work schedule permits. All work required for the installation of such sewer lines and manholes which cannot be done with city employees and city-owned equipment shall be the responsibility of the subdivider. If the subdivider does not install such public sanitary sewers, the subdivider shall install individual sewage disposal devices for each lot at the time improvements are erected thereon. All such individual sewage disposal systems shall be constructed in accordance with health department's specifications. The subdivider shall receive approval for each individual sewage disposal system from the health department prior to the issuance of a building permit. (f) Where public water supply is reasonably accessible to the subdivision, each lot within the subdivision shall be provided with a connection thereto. The subdivider shall be responsible for the payment of all materials for the installation of the water system in the subdivision, and the city shall provide the labor for the installation of such water system at such time as the city's work schedule permits. Where public water supply is not reasonably accessible to the subdivision, the subdivider shall construct wells or a private water supply system in such a manner that an adequate supply of potable water will be available to every lot in the subdivision. The adequacy, healthfulness and potableness of the water supply shall be subject to the approval of the health department. The subdivider shall receive approval for any such wells or private water supply system from the health department prior to the issuance of any building permit. (g) In the subdivision where a public water supply is provided, fire hydrants shall be installed at such locations as required by the engineer. Payment for same shall be as provided in paragraph (f) above. (h) All streets in the subdivision shall be paved, curbed and guttered. The city shall be responsible for paying one-third of the cost of the labor and materials for the curbing and guttering in the subdivision, and the subdivider shall be responsible for two-thirds of the cost of the labor and materials for such curbing and guttering. The subdivider shall be responsible for all costs of the paving of the streets within the subdivision. (i) The subdivider shall develop a lighting plan for the subdivision which shall meet the approval of the city engineer and/or city building inspector. Each light in the subdivision shall be connected to a residence and paid for by the subdivider and/or resident(s) of the subdivision. (j) All improvements required under this section shall be constructed in accordance with standards specified by the city and with the approval of the city engineer, and all construction shall be under the supervision of and accepted by the city engineer. (k) All improvements required under this section may be done in phases in the development of the subdivision, as approved by the city engineer and/or city building inspector. (l) As a condition precedent to the contract for improvements between the subdivider and the city, the subdivider shall furnish to the city such assurance as may be required by the city for the ultimate completion of the improvements in the subdivision as set forth above. (m) Should the subdivider fail to comply with any of the terms of this section or the contract entered into with the city, the city may revoke the entire contract with the subdivider and the approval of the subdivision, and thereafter refuse to grant any permits for building in said subdivision. (n) The contract and all plans and specifications for improvements required herein shall be kept and maintained as a permanent record by the city. (Ord. of 9-16-1975, § 1; Ord. of 5-20-1986, § 2; Ord. of 5-4-1993, § 3; Ord. of 12-1-1998) Section 1302. - Bond for improvements. To insure the installation of the improvements required by section 1301 hereof, the subdivider shall furnish a surety bond executed by a surety acceptable to the board of commissioners for the City of Jesup in an amount equal to the estimated cost of construction of such required improvements as determined by the city engineer. Section 1303. - Parks and public places. Where a proposed park, playground or other public use area, shown in the city plan, is located in whole or in part in a subdivision, the board of commissioners may require the dedication or reservation of such area within the subdivision when the board of commissioners shall deem such requirements to be reasonable; provided, however, that just and adequate compensation shall be paid the owner for such property. Section 1304. - Labor cost for water/sewer line installation; credits towards ad valorem taxes. The City of Jesup will furnish the labor for installation of the water lines and/or sewer lines within the subdivision, when the city labor forces are capable of performing such work and within its manpower and/or budgetary capabilities. In the event that the subdivider installs within the subdivision water and/or sewer lines connected to the city water and/or city sewer system, then the city will credit the cost of labor towards the subdivider's ad valorem taxes each year until such costs are fully paid; provided, however, all such labor costs of the subdivider shall be approved by the city prior to the commencement of any such work. The ad valorem tax credits for such work may be transferred by the subdivider to subsequent owners of the property involved in such improvements, with the written consent of the city. All such water and/or sewer line improvements of the subdivider shall be conveyed to the city upon completion of the installation of such improvements. (Ord. of 5-4-1993, § 6; Ord. of 12-1-1998, § 1) ARTICLE XIV - SEVERABILITY It is intended that the provisions of this ordinance be severable and should any portion be held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect any other portion of this ordinance. ARTICLE XV - REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES The subdivision ordinance of the City of Jesup adopted September 21, 1954, as amended, is hereby repealed in its entirety. ARTICLE XVI. - EFFECTIVE DATE
Section 1601. - Effective date of ordinance. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force after the date of its adoption, the public welfare demanding it. Adopted by the board of commissioners of Jesup, Georgia, this eighth day of July, 1969. APPENDIX C - FEE SCHEDULE
